SE Opinion
HD NDP MP: Six questions surrounding Trans Mountain Pipeline
WC 655 words
PD 25 April 2018
SN Trail Daily Times
SC TRAILD
ED Final
LA English
CY Copyright 2018 Black Press, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Trail Daily Times -- The Trans Mountain Expansion pipeline has dominated news in the past few weeks. The public is divided over whether we should build this pipeline and allow Alberta oil sands output to increase, or whether it presents too much risk to BC's rivers and coastal environments.

Many experts described the original project approval process as deeply flawed. The Liberals ignored their campaign promise of a new, improved process and instead sent a ministerial panel along the pipeline route in the summer of 2016. Many communities and First Nations governments criticized this process as inadequate as well. However the panel did write a report that ended with a list of six clear questions for the government to answer before making a decision.

TD 

I think it would be useful to review those questions to see more clearly how we got into this quagmire.

1. Can construction of a new Trans Mountain Pipeline be reconciled with Canada's climate change commitments? Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr often proclaims "This pipeline will be built", but I have never heard him say "We will meet our Paris targets." For many pipeline opponents this is the crux of the problem.

2. In the absence of a comprehensive national energy strategy, how can policy-makers effectively assess projects such as the Trans Mountain Pipeline? Canada needs a national energy strategy that would answer broader questions such as: what role new pipelines would play in a world where world oil demand (according to the National Energy Board itself) will begin declining in 2019; how we might refine our oil resources for our own use rather than exporting bitumen and importing foreign oil on the Atlantic coast; and how we can create good jobs in renewable energy as the world shifts to a low carbon future.

3. How might Cabinet square approval of the Trans Mountain Pipeline with its commitment to reconciliation with First Nations and to the UNDRIP principles of "free, prior, and informed consent?" This is perhaps the key question that the federal government failed to answer before it approved the Trans Mountain Expansion. There is strong opposition to the project from many First Nations, and a number of lawsuits are in the courts arguing that the approval process did not involve proper consultation. If this is found to be the case (as it was in the Northern Gateway pipeline decision) it could delay the project another year or more.

4. Given the changed economic and political circumstances, the perceived flaws in the NEB process, and also the criticism of the Ministerial Panel's own review, how can Canada be confident in its assessment of the project's economic rewards and risks? According to Nanos Research only 2% of Canadians have strong confidence in Canada's energy regulation system, a fact that bears on the discontent seen on both sides of this debate.

5. If approved, what route would best serve aquifer, municipal, aquatic and marine safety? Kinder Morgan has not yet asked the government for approval of the exact route for much of the pipeline; in many cases the old route will not be followed, especially in the Lower Mainland.

6. How does federal policy define the terms "social license" and "Canadian public interest" and their inter-relationships? Through the election campaign, Justin Trudeau repeated the mantra "governments can grant permits, but only communities grant permission". The federal government now finds itself in a very difficult situation, having to tell coastal British Columbians that the project is in the national interest.

It is now too late to answer these questions before Kinder Morgan's self-imposed deadline of May 31, but we would have been in a much better situation had the government fully dealt with them before approving the Trans Mountain expansion project.

Richard Cannings is the MP for South Okanagan-West Kootenay

Copyright 2018 Trail Daily Times


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Black Press Inc.

AN 
Document TRAILD0020180426ee4p00004


The failure of social license
Hanna Herald (Alberta), 20:00, 18 April 2018, 454 words, Rick Strankman, (English)
Margaret Thatcher served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 until 1990. She was not only the first woman to become Prime Minister; she was also the longest serving Prime Minister of the United Kingdom in the 20th century. She...

SE Op-Ed
HD Susan Martinuk: Trudeau has failed to resolve pipeline crisis
BY Harvey Enchin
WC 686 words
PD 17 April 2018
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2018 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is traveling through Europe this week, standing shoulder-to-shoulder with world leaders as he charmingly promotes Canada as a nation that is open for investment.

Meanwhile, we at home are left to muse about Trudeau's seeming inability to ensure that such opportunity truly exists in Canada and for Canadians.

TD 

Despite his many promises, Trudeau has done nothing to ensure the Kinder Morgan pipeline will become a reality. His unwillingness to take an authoritative and supportive stand behind the project now has investors in the $7.4-billion pipeline prepared to take their dollars elsewhere. Thousands of jobs, the viability of Alberta's economy and Canada's "open for business" status are all at stake, yet Trudeau appears content to remain on the sidelines as tensions rise across the country, with threats of interprovincial trade wars and constitutional challenges.

After years of careful reviews and innumerable environmental studies, the National Energy Board, the federal government and the prime minister all concluded that the pipeline is safe. Every court challenge has ruled in favour of the project going ahead.

Yet noisy protestors have somehow managed to strip away the legitimacy of the authority that stands behind those decisions. They refuse to recognize the rule of law, in part because Trudeau himself has allowed them to become legitimate influencers of his energy policy.

In 2015, he said that pipelines were the most responsible way to get oil to markets, but then added that pipelines "have to achieve the public trust and the social license that is necessary." Social license? Cue the protestors. With that one comment, Trudeau has given them equal standing with facts, science and the rule of law.

Trudeau has long been a master of doublespeak, using his smile and adorable socks to take the edge off words that might offend. Even as he promises to build a pipeline, he has promised to "phase out" the oilsands (the very same oilsands for which he claims he is building the Kinder Morgan pipeline). He has said he is committed to moving oil out of Alberta, yet has sold his soul to the environmentalists with his unquestioning support for carbon taxes as a means of influencing climate change.

Sunday's pipeline summit in Ottawa lasted just a couple of hours and proved to be just one more demonstration of Trudeau's inability to exert federal authority for a project that is, in his own words, "of vital strategic interest to Canada." He offered his usual prime ministerial promises to get the pipeline built and even vowed to invest Canadian dollars as a surety of his government's support. In doing so, Trudeau played the kind of politics that Canadians most loathe - throwing taxpayer money at a problem that could (and should) have been handled previously and sans lucre.

In addition, Trudeau did nothing to reduce interprovincial tensions. Alberta Premier Rachel Notley has since introduced legislation to stop the flow of oil to B.C., while Premier John Horgan has vowed to continue to resist just so he can stay in power. Saskatchewan and Quebec are now getting involved and investigating possible actions in support of Alberta and B.C., respectively.

The whole country seems on the cusp of a crisis. Well done, Mr. Trudeau.

Not surprisingly, when a Vancouver Sun online poll asked readers if they were surprised by the outcome of the so-called pipeline summit, 80 per cent agreed with the comment, "No, this is exactly how I thought it would play out."

It's not exactly support for Trudeau as a man of action. Rather, it's confirmation that Trudeau has played both sides of this debate for too long - neither side sees him as able to restore federal authority over the provinces or provide the necessary support for a megaproject of vital interest to Canadians.

"Lead, follow, or get out of the way." It's a basic axiom for successful leadership. Mr. Trudeau would do well to consider it.

Susan Martinuk is a Vancouver-based columnist.


NS 
nedc : Commentaries/Opinions | genv : Natural Environment | gcat : Political/General News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpex : C&E Executive News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

IPD 
prime,minister,justin,trudeau,traveling,through

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020180417ee4h006ss


HD Strategy Session
WC 2651 words
PD 16 April 2018
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: Welcome back. Well, there's oodles of debatable political strategy being deployed all over Ottawa today. That makes it a particularly good time to bring in the capital's best strategic brains. Kate Harrison is with Summa Strategies, Greg Weston with Earnscliffe, Karl Belanger, former NDP strategist and Greg MacEachern , henceforth known as G-Mac to avoid gregarious confusion between the two, is with Proof Strategies. Nice to have you all back.

TD 

KATE HARRISON (Summa Strategies): Thank you.

MARTIN: G-Mac...

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: All right, let's get right to this Trudeau thing. He has this emergency summit on the weekend. I, sort of, suggested he had, sort of, a Rambo thing going on with the pipelines. Karl, is this enough to overcome, sort of, the image of the selfie king, or...?

KARL BELANGER (NDP Strategist): I don't think so.

MARTIN: Why, why not?

BELANGER: I don't think the pipeline is any closer to being built than it was before the summit. You have a vague plan of maybe partially nationalizing the pipeline, and then you have a law that's going to be tabled to reaffirm that you have jurisdiction, but if you have jurisdiction, why do you need the law reaffirm it. It's very unclear. Basically, he's trying to buy time and, and reassure investors. But it's still a stalemate. There's still no, no progress. We'll see what happens.

MARTIN: Greg?

GREG WESTON (Earnscliffe Strategy Group): Yeah, that's about where I am.

(LAUGHTER)

WESTON: I see, what's the best-case scenario is they pour a bunch of public money into this, and then you get the grandmothers still turning out to stand in front of the bulldozers. I mean, the biggest thing that is going to stop this pipeline is not going to be money. It's not going to be legalities. It's not going to be regulations. It's going to be, does this government have the stomach to, for day after day of really ugly, public confrontations? And in past, the answer generally is no, and I'm not sure this government is any different.

MARTIN: I guess, and particularly with a lot of indigenous people might be joining that protest, the optics are going to be pretty hard to correlate with reconciliation, I guess.

HARRISON: Yeah, there's no doubt that this is a political hot potato for the Liberals, and I don't think any opposition party envies the situation that, that they're in. I think we can all agree that the meeting itself was the right thing to do, and the right call, but where we might disagree is at what point that meeting should have happened. So, certainly had this conversation started a bit earlier, maybe five, six months ago, or you know, not long after John Horgan got elected in, in June last year, maybe we would be in a different position than we are now. But certainly, it's a, it's a challenging file but had intervention happened earlier, we may have not had the need for the meeting on Sunday.

MARTIN: What, was it a necessary summit, in your view, Greg or G-Mac, sorry?

(LAUGHTER)

GREG MACEACHERN (Proof Strategies): The meeting, absolutely. I think for one thing, Canadians aren't really familiar with the British Columbia premier. Now they've gotten a chance to see him. I think they are familiar with Notley. And I think, you know, you just need to do this so that you can say this has been done. To Kate's point, though, I think there have been conversations between the prime minister and the BC premier where he's been offered things about, I think Trudeau understands the political position that he's in. I think the NDP understand it. You and I both know the column last week where the NDP had to reveal in BC that on day one, they received advice that if they chose to live up to their campaign promise...

MARTIN: Right.

MACEACHERN: ...which was to fight this pipeline at any cost, they would be sued. You notice now the premier of BC has changed his language on this. I think the other thing is we've seen from the opposition party no great ideas, and I think that is kind of telling about how tough a situation it is. Jagmeet Singh got laughed out of Ottawa within minutes by the premier of Alberta. And Scheer, I, was it budget day? What was the rush to try to get a message out before the meeting even happened? So, I don't think you can look to the opposition parties and say, well, they've got great ideas. The prime minister should listen to them. This is an easy out.

MARTIN: Greg, I'm curious if you...

WESTON: Could I just say one thing to this, Don.

MARTIN: Okay. Always.

WESTON: Sorry. I think the most important thing about what happened yesterday was the photo-op. You know, Canadians hear this great barrage of we're going to do this and you're going to do that and we're against this and it all becomes just white noise after a while. What they saw yesterday was the prime minister sitting down with the premiers of the two provinces. There's a, a photo of them smiling. There's a clip of them all smiling for the cameras. And the prime minister is kind of seated at the, what looks like the head of the table. It's actually in one chair versus two sofas that the other two were on. So I think that sort of gives people the sense that, okay, this is Canada. Our brawls at least are friendly. Everybody's still smiling. There's something happening there. There's at least hope for this that we're not into a stand-off.

HARRISON: Unless things don't go through, because then that's the photo they'll use on June 1st if Kinder Morgan actually decides not to proceed with this.

MARTIN: I'm still bedazzled by the fact that Greg Weston, who I've known for 20 years, is bedazzled by a photo-op. I've never heard that before.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: But you know, one thing that was missing in that photo, Karl, I don't know if you think it's a big deal, or not - no indigenous representation at all. Was that smart that we kept that just to the premiers and the prime minister? Or should they have had someone there, because they're divided? There's a lot of division in the First Nations community along that route.

BELANGER: There is a lot of division. But I think it's probably a mistake to keep them at bay here, and especially considering the promise that the prime minister made during the campaign, which was basically to consult Aboriginals and First Nations, all, all along this process. Not doing it. And the key thing is that, you know, to build this pipeline, the prime minister needs social license. If he doesn't have social license, he needs political will. At this point, I'm not sure he's got either.

WESTON: And who exactly is the indigenous leader, or representative, who is going to be there?

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MACEACHERN: Well, that's probably why they're not in the room.

BELANGER: But...

MACEACHERN: I don't know. Trudeau keeps saying that this is going to be built. I think that's huge political will. That's what you're going to see. Not that photo. You're going to see clips and clips of him saying this pipeline is going to be built. That's why I think I'm very confident that they're going to find a way to do this.

MARTIN: Hmm. Are you?

HARRISON: He has been saying that since the beginning. Now, he actually hasn't waffled on his position that he wants to see this built. But what's been missing is the action to get there. And he has been saying it for a long time, and we still have Kinder Morgan wavering about whether, or not, they have the climate to proceed. So, we'll see what's in the legislation. We'll see how much money the government is willing to put behind this because that has, that wasn't answered yesterday...

MARTIN: Right.

HARRISON: ...is how much are they actually going to pay for this?

MARTIN: And whether it's equity or just backstopping losses...

HARRISON: That's right.

MARTIN: ...is another question, you know?

MACEACHERN: Or environmental safeguards .

MARTIN: Okay. I want to move along. I was going to ask about Daniel Jean, but I'm not sure, did anyone think that was a really huge...

MACEACHERN: This was the worst case of broken, game of broken telephone ever. And we just saw how Ottawa breaks down between reporters, the opposition and government. I think if they had put him out earlier, the government would be in a much better place.

MARTIN: Yeah.

MACEACHERN: I think he did a great job for the government today. He really cooled things. Mr. Scheer said, gee, if Trudeau had done this earlier, during your interview, well, to me, that says that the opposition didn't get a big win today.

MARTIN: You were wincing a little bit there, Mr. Weston.

WESTON: Well, you know, one thing, and I'll just mention it, having been around for a few years, I think this is the first time that I've ever seen the national security advisor inject himself into a public discussion about anything. I mean, they just don't show up very often.

MARTIN: Right.

WESTON: And so it's kind of interesting from that perspective. Why would, why would he go out there and do this? And I think he, I think he did it for all the right reasons. If there's one person in government who I would actually trust, for what they're saying, for what they're telling you, it would be the national security advisor. And if he says it didn't happen, I would be inclined to believe him.

MARTIN: Yeah. Kate, I'm wondering what the missing part of this narrative is now, because it looks to me like he said the story that he basically told the journalists. I didn't see a whole lot of things he told the journalists that are yet to be unclassified, if you will.

HARRISON: Right. Well, and that kind of begs the question as to why the government was, sort of, dragging their heels on having him appear at committee in the first place. I think we all agree that had they come out earlier, we'd be maybe in a different situation. But there was this...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MACEACHERN: ...precedent, as Greg Weston just said.

WESTON: Well, not only that, but the guy who's got all the secrets in government, and all the secrets, he is the national security advisor. He's the guy who deals with the CIA and the NSA and...

HARRISON: Of course, but that's what makes for...

WESTON: You don't want to put him in front of a parliamentary committee.

HARRISON: That's what makes his testimony so, so important, though, is that gravitas and that knowledge and that power he has. So, for this initial story to come out saying that he was, you know, putting this idea forward that the Indian government was involved or that was alleged national security, or senior authority and national security, that's what made today so important. We still don't have an answer on Atwal in spite of that.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

WESTON: It, it's possible that everybody in government was as stunned as I was that this became, is still actually a story over this one guy who showed up for lunch.

MARTIN: Karl?

BELANGER: I think, I think that the reason they were dragging their heels is because this was embarrassing. They were embarrassed, and I think the story is now probably winding down because there's not...

WESTON: Oh, thank god.

BELANGER: ...there's not much here, but the opposition dragged it along for a very long time, so in that sense, I disagree with G-Mac.

MARTIN: Yeah.

BELANGER: It's a win for the opposition to have to carry this quite so long.

MACEACHERN: I don't know if I said that.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: Well, let's quickly go down here. We've only got a couple of minutes left. The Liberals are huddling in Halifax at the end of this week to sort of push the, get some policy ideas, the last time they gathered as a group to come up with some new ideas before the election campaign. But I'm wondering, do they need a reset? Do they need a reset, this government? Or are they doing fine the way they are?

BELANGER: I don't think they need a reset. I don't think they need new ideas. They just need to look at their last platform and start implementing it. That would be a nice thing to do.

MARTIN: Greg? That's you.

WESTON: This is, this is...

MARTIN: It's you, Greg. Not this Greg. He's G-Mac. You're Greg.

WESTON: Okay. All right. Every once in a while you need to get all the troops together and at least have a pep rally. They're eighteen months before the next election. They're very much starting to move into election mode. There are, this is unusual for this government. This is the first time that they've had a sustained dip in public opinion polls. It's making a lot of the backbenchers and a lot of the ground troops are going to need for that election campaign who they need them to start working now.

MARTIN: Yeah.

WESTON: Are going to need to hear a little bit of pep rally and know that the world is still good, that it's not really falling apart.

MARTIN: Kate?

HARRISON: Yeah, it's going to be a rah-rah in Halifax for sure. And conventions have the potential to be a bit of bloodletting, as well, and we may see a bit of that on the fringe, although, you know, I, I'm doubtful about that. You know, it's a tricky time in the mandate, and when you are going into convention having, you know, not had a platform or ads, etcetera, which is what Scheer will benefit from later this year. For the existing government, that's a little bit more of a challenge because they have to defend the record and put their plan forward.

MARTIN: Thirty seconds to you.

MACEACHERN: If you look at the mandate letters, a lot of stuff is done, but I think if they prorogue, the problem is, you look at the record. The House has not been their strength. I think they need a number three person who loves parliament like they love a church, and that they really try to get the mandate through there, but I think if they prorogue, people are going to look at the record, not the mandate letters. It's the last convention before the election. So I'm just hoping not to be the broken man on the Halifax pier by Sunday morning.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: You are bad.

BELANGER: What's the over/under on that?

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: All right. Thank you all. That was fun. All right, coming up, Alberta declares legislative war against BC. The minister explains her pipeline retaliation plan next. Please stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

RE 
ottaw : Ottawa | cana : Canada | caon : Ontario | namz : North America

Bell Media Inc.

AN 
Document ONHILL0020180418ee4g0005o


HD The Scrum Part I
WC 2026 words
PD 15 April 2018
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): EVAN SOLOMON

TD 

EVAN SOLOMON: Welcome back to "Question Period". Well, the stakes could not be higher. The prime minister is, right now, in an emergency meeting with the premiers of BC and Alberta. He's clearly desperate to emerge with a way to get the Trans Mountain pipeline built. Earlier in the program, the natural resource minister, Jim Carr, strongly hinted that the government will financially support the pipeline, so Kinder Morgan doesn't pull the plug on it before their May 31st deadline. Clearly though, BC opposes it. And Alberta's ready to start a trade war over it. What does the prime minister have to deliver today? We're waiting for them all to emerge from this meeting. So, it could happen at any moment, and we'll go live to that, but the scrum is here waiting for that. Laura Stone, reporter with the Globe and Mail is here; Craig Oliver, CTV's chief political commentator is here; and Bob Fife, the Globe and Mail's Ottawa bureau chief is here. Look, we don't know. At any moment, they could emerge. We're expecting, actually, the BC premier, Mr. Horgan, to emerge first. I don't know, he seems intractable. Bob, what are you expecting the government to emerge from this meeting with?

ROBERT FIFE (The Globe and Mail): Well, federal officials are saying they did not expect any kind of significant movement from Premier Horgan on that. So they already have their game plan. Their game plan, as one official said to me, the main objective is to remove during the period of construction, the risk that the company can't or won't do. And so what we're going to expect later today when the prime minister makes an announcement, I think, around 1:00 o'clock, he will announce that Finance Minister Bill Morneau will now open discussions with the company on a number of options. One of them is, do you take an equity stake in this? Or do we provide some kind of risk insurance? There are other options. A big trigger is, do they expropriate the pipeline route? That's probably going to be mentioned in that meeting, which may give heart palpitations to Premier Horgan. Whether we'll actually go that route, I don't know. And they will certainly be told with, raise the issue of let's take this to the Supreme Court. The feds have already done their homework on that. They do not believe that the court would see this as an emergency, and besides that, it would take twelve to eighteen months for a court to make that kind of hearing, and we have the deadline marching on to May 31st.

SOLOMON: All right. Likely financial backing, likely invoking what's called expropriation, which means the government can just expropriate the land, and that's a flexing of federal jurisdiction muscles. Sources also telling me, don't expect a firm detailed plan financially. It's not like Bill Morneau and the prime minister are going to come out and say we're buying this pipeline. They are going to outline a process to get there. So, I would not look for details. That's what I'm hearing right now. Laura?

LAURA STONE (The Globe and Mail): I think it's four against one in that room, in the prime minister's office, right now, on Parliament Hill. There is immense pressure on John Horgan to save face, and I think that the message to him is how little do you want to be humiliated in this fight? They're going to try to paint him as extremely unreasonable on this. The prime minister is going to come out with all the environment protections that they've given to the oceans. That's going to be a big focus of his media availability today, I suspect. And so the message in there, I think why they're going so long is they're trying to pitch to John Horgan, how can you get out of this alive, because they know he's not going to change his mind.

SOLOMON: Craig?

CRAIG OLIVER (CTV News): Well, for Alberta, this is really the last chance saloon. I mean, that's what's at stake here. They will never have another chance, probably, to get Alberta oil to Canadian tidewater. The country has a lot to lose here, too, many will, many will say. I think this meeting will come out, if Bob is right, and he always is, with all sides having taken a decision, say good-bye to the great old Canadian compromise. They will have been taken an irreconcilable position from which they cannot retreat. The question is, is it going to be enough for Kinder Morgan?

SOLOMON: Right. Here's what we, we do expect Premier Horgan to be the first one out of this meeting. We'll take it live. Just expect him to say he is not giving an inch. There's no indication, and the federal government sources have told all of us this, that Horgan will give an inch. For him, Bob, is this all just political theatre? He's got to show his constituency, which is the Green party, I ain't going to be bullied.

FIFE: Well, what he is, really, is the puppet of the Green leader in BC, who is really, he's, he's the guy who's...

SOLOMON: Andrew Weaver.

FIFE: Andrew Weaver's the man who's making this guy go up and down. Mr. Trudeau had tried, early on, to work with Premier Horgan. He said, in privately, to him, look, let's, we've got to get this pipeline built. Ask me what concessions you want. You come out. I'll say, oh, I had to give into these things. It'll make you look good. And he wouldn't do so. And so they don't really trust this guy anymore, because they've given him some options, and he doesn't want to play. And he doesn't want to play because he doesn't want to lose his government.

SOLOMON: I'll tell you now, now, Laura, you said it's four against one, because the finance minister, the natural resource minister, Jim Carr, the prime minister are all in the room with Rachel Notley and Premier Horgan. I'll tell who's not in the room? There is no First Nations representative. And we spoke to the national chief of the Assembly of First Nations, Perry Bellegarde, about this. And they are livid that they have been excluded from this summit. Here's what Perry Bellegarde said.

NATIONAL CHIEF PERRY BELLEGARDE (Assembly of First Nations): I think it's a very big miss for the government. You've got the federal crown. You've got the provincial crowns. You're missing out the rights and titleholders. And that's the most important element. We have the right to self-determination. The rights and titleholders have to be involved.

SOLOMON: Okay, Perry Bellegarde saying it's a big mistake. How big a mistake?

STONE: This is a huge oversight on the part of the federal government. How can they say that they're negotiating in good faith with First Nations when you hold this extremely important meeting on Parliament Hill, and you exclude a voice from that community? I'm very shocked, in fact. I think it just shows how quickly this whole meeting was slapped together, as the prime minister was taking off for Peru. So, I think it's a big oversight, and it's going to do damage, I believe, to their reconciliation agenda.

OLIVER: I'm not so sure that it is that big a mistake.

STONE: Oh, Craig...

OLIVER: An awful lot of First Nations don't agree with the coastal chiefs.

STONE: But that doesn't mean they have to be against it.

OLIVER: And furthermore, if they're there, why are they there? Are they there, is that suggesting that they have a veto over resource development? And that's a huge issue. The Supreme Court has never said they do.

STONE: Well, it says they have a voice.

SOLOMON: But Perry...

OLIVER: So, are they there just to listen? That's not power. This is a time for political decision-making.

SOLOMON: Perry Bellegarde said that First Nations, of course, are divided on this, as many other Canadians are. But this was the most important file for Justin Trudeau. To exclude a First Nations voice there, and Perry Bellegarde...

FIFE: Well, you know, I disagree with Laura, as well because that's not the place for the Assembly of First Nations to be dealing with the provincial government, dealing with two resource issues. And I'll tell you the other thing, who does Perry Bellegarde speak for? There are 600 status bands that he represents, and they are at each other's throats, too. I mean, he can't get agreement on a lot of things. So...

SOLOMON: This, this is optics. This is about social license. And Laura, I've got to tell you, I believe that the prime minister...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

SOLOMON: ...not, not having a First Nations voice...

FIFE: If you had them in that meeting, it would be more of a mess.

STONE: And it doesn't mean it's in opposition. It's representing all the diverse views. It doesn't mean he's going to go and say we want to stop the pipeline, but he could present the different points of view of First Nations that he represents. Of course, it's on everyone.

SOLOMON: Perry Bellegarde, Perry Bellegarde was adamant. He said that pipeline, without First Nations, cannot be built. And when they're not there, the optics, I think, are very bad for that. And I think that, that could be very damaging. And I wonder, Craig, if that leads to very big protests.

OLIVER: This will be, if this pipeline goes ahead, it will be the biggest example of civil disobedience in Canadian history. It will be violent. It will be massive law breaking. Remember, Clayoquot Sound in 1993, 900 people went to jail. But that was way out in the woods. Nobody could get there. This is downtown Vancouver. It will be ugly and the prime minister will be seen to be behind those bulldozers and the people in front of the bulldozers will be the people who, for years, have been his biggest supporters. Indigenous people and environmentalists. It will be a mess for Trudeau.

SOLOMON: All right, Bob, last word.

FIFE: Well, I'm just not sure that the people who are going to be campaigning against the Kinder Morgan are supporters of Justin Trudeau. I think they're supporters of the Green party. They're supporters more of the NDP - not the Liberal party.

SOLOMON: All right.

OLIVER: Like the Trudeau of the past, who was an environmentalist, and campaigned as an environmentalist...

SOLOMON: Well that, well, listen, okay. So, here's where we are right now, folks. As we're standing by on a special edition here of CTV's "Question Period" and the scrum, we are waiting for the first premier to emerge from this meeting. They were supposed to emerge about 40 minutes ago. Clearly, that's maybe a good sign that it's not short. We were all wondering if Horgan walks out quickly, that's a bad sign. They're still in the meeting right now. We don't expect Horgan to have a concession, but the longer they're there, the more there's a possibility that there's some movement. We do expect the federal government to come out and announce some kind of support for the pipeline. We are standing by right here for that. Stay with us here. Live coverage of this emergency pipeline summit going on literally right behind us, right now, right here, on CTV's "Question Period". Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HD Opposition Reacts to Pipeline Issue
WC 1845 words
PD 15 April 2018
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): EVAN SOLOMON

JUSTIN TRUDEAU (Canadian Prime Minister): The question is not whether the pipeline is going to get built. The question is how the pipeline gets built. And we are looking at all options.

TD 

SOLOMON: Well the stakes could not be higher for the prime minister today. Rushing back from the conference in Peru, Justin Trudeau is now hosting an urgent meeting with the premiers of BC and Alberta to try to find a way to make sure the Trans Mountain pipeline is going to get built. But the company, the proponent, Kinder Morgan, they own the pipeline, they've set a deadline, get this going before May 31st or we will kill it. Now we just heard from the minister of natural resources, Jim Carr, tell us that the government is ready to do everything they can to make sure the pipeline gets built. He used the word de-risk, which might mean paying for it. Is that enough? Joining us from Calgary, Conservative MP Michelle Rempel; and in Victoria, we're joined by the NDP MP Murray Rankin. Great to have both of you here. Michelle Rempel, let me start with you. What more do you think the government can do to make sure this pipeline gets built?

MICHELLE REMPEL (Conservative – Alberta): They can invoke section 92.10 C of the Constitution Act to ensure that any remaining issues that have provincial jurisdiction fall into federal purview. They can make sure that any court cases that Premier Horgan might put forward to try and delay the pipeline becomes directly referred to the Supreme Court. They can scrap Bill C-69 which the pipeline association has said if this bill goes through there will be no more pipelines built in Canada. They can enforce the rule of law in terms of protests. You know, I could go on and on. The thing that you just said, de-risk, this is what Jim Carr just said to you. They want to use taxpayer dollars to, I'm assuming it will be like a guarantee or something, Evan, all they want to do is kick this down the road past the election so that their BC Liberal MPs can get re-elected. So when you think about that, when you think about the fact that they ask Canadians to pay a carbon tax to get social license to get this built, which it didn't, and now they want federal tax dollars to de-risk it for them. This isn't about de-risking it for Kinder Morgan or for energy sector workers, this is about politically de-risking it in the hopes that it will die somewhere after the election. And that is disgusting, and every Canadian, regardless of what side of the pipeline debate they're on, should be holding the government to attack. It's just fekless arrogance. It's disgusting.

SOLOMON: Okay, strong words there. They say they're trying to de-risk it, Murray Rankin. In other words, to try to get out of this May 31st deadline in some way, and support Rachel Notley's idea of investing in the pipeline. What's your view of what they're doing?

MURRAY RANKIN (NDP – BC): Well, first of all, May 31st is a deadline set by a Houston-based company. Since when do allow American companies to tell us what to do in Canada? We have a federal government. We have provincial governments that do that. We wouldn't be in this mess, as you know, I think, if it weren't for the fact that Mr. Trudeau came to my riding of Victoria in the election when he was a candidate and said, you know, we're going to redo this whole process, and look at how diluted bitumen performs in marine environment, get First Nations better involved, etcetera. They didn't do any of that. Now we are faced with two things. We're faced with massive opposition to this on our coast, and we're faced with a provincial government of Mr. Horgan that has a strong mandate from the people to oppose the risk, to deal with the risks that this pipeline is going to create.

SOLOMON: Now this meeting, this summit, Michelle Rempel, he's have got Rachel Notley in a room, and he's got Mr. Premier Horgan in the room, and he's got to come up with something. Horgan's political life depends on opposing this. He's in a coalition with the Green Party. They don't want the pipeline. They're trying to either, "A", delay it to death, they don't want to do it. They say they have jurisdiction over the environment. What does Justin Trudeau have to say to Premier Horgan right now?

REMPEL: Find his spine and be the prime minister of Canada. This is a project that's in the national interest that passed one of the most rigorous environmental review processes in the world. We are not talking with Venezuela or Saudi Arabia. And, you know, Murray's comment about we won't let Houston-based organizations tell us where to go, that organization is about to put $7.4 billion into the Canadian economy. And, frankly, how much money have American environmental NGOs put into the opposition of this pipe pipeline? So I find it a little rich that an NDP MP, who many organizations that are funding the anti-pipeline protests have money from outside of the country. To me this is about a project that unites the country. I mean I have a lot of respect for Murray. The reality is, though, is that this isn't just about British Columbia, this isn't about Alberta. This is a project that's in the national interest. To me, this is, it's mindboggling that Trudeau won't just come out and say there are five or six things that need to be done. Bailing out this project will not do those things. He has to get those things done first. And I just, you know, it's very frustrating. RANKIN: Evan, I respect Michelle enormously, but we're proud Canadians on the west coast too, and I resent this notion that Mr. Trudeau is brandishing the term the national interest around as if somehow be standing up for our oceans, standing with First Nations, standing in favour of endangered killer whales, that somehow we're less Canadian. I resent that implication tremendously. People out here are proud.

SOLOMON: Mr. Rankin, just to be fair, the term national interest is a legal term of what's in the, to invoke what's in the national interest and the federal jurisdiction. But let me just try to understand, just a second. Let me just, and you're a lawyer, so you know this, I'm trying to appreciate the NDP's position. Your leader, Jagmeet Singh, says he doesn't support the pipeline, but then he says he wants to go to court to try to understand if the government, the federal government has the jurisdiction to build it. My question to you, if the courts decide, if it went to court, that the government does have the jurisdiction, would he flip his support and suddenly the federal NDP would support this pipeline?

RANKIN: His position has been I thought constructive to try to suggest that we have a reference to the Supreme Court of Canada, which we can do very quickly with the support of the government of British Columbia, the government of Canada, perhaps First Nations, perhaps Alberta. We can go and get a quick ruling on whether or not British Columbia's jurisdiction over air, land, and water, which all provinces have, give it some ability to stop this project, or at least to have a change in regulations at the provincial level to address the legitimate concerns that a province like British Columbia has. Now if the court comes up with a clear statement that, no, British Columbia, you have no jurisdiction at all in the face of a federal undertaking, then of course we believe in the rule of law.

SOLOMON: Okay, so then you would support, that's interesting. So then Mr. Singh would say, yes, I support the pipeline. I just want to get that clear.

RANKIN: He would, he's a lawyer. He understands that the court has spoken. Now whether or not there are other issues that need to be addressed outside of the legal process is another thing. But you're asking what that would mean in terms of a legal argument, of course he would have to abide and accept the judgment of the Supreme Court of Canada.

SOLOMON: Michelle Rempel?

REMPEL: What you have here, Evan, is you've got two political parties that do not want this pipeline built. So what we have seen over the last 10 years is these two political parties use the environmental review process to put in place uncertainty with the hope that these projects will just die or go away without them having to make the political decision, or the words coming out of their mouth we do not want this pipeline built. And that's what Murray just danced around. This is really the shamefulness of this. I would actually, I would rather have the discussion where, you know, I remember sitting with an NDP candidate during the election on national TV where she just said, you know, oil should stay in the ground. I would rather have that debate than the sort of...

RANKIN: We're not talking about that. That is not our position.

REMPEL: Yeah, but we are. We are. That is where the...

RANKIN: No. Absolutely not! REMPEL: That is where, that's where the debate is at right now. So why should we raise taxpayer resources guaranteeing things, tying up the court.

RANKIN: Well the debate is Mr. Carr is talking about de-risking.

REMPEL: De-risking for who? For politicians!

RANKIN: Yeah, exactly. Exactly! What does that do?

REMPEL: This just needs to get built.

RANKIN: What does that do? What does the ownership of part of this pipeline by the governments of Alberta and Canada have to do the legal jurisdiction at all? Nothing!

REMPEL: Kinder Morgan didn't ask for the nationalization. Kinder Morgan did not ask for the nationalization of energy infrastructure. And frankly the last time a socialist nationalized Canada's energy industry, it didn't go so well.

SOLOMON: Okay. I got to leave it there, Murray Rankin and Michelle Rempel. We'll find out more today what does happen. Thanks so much for joining us. Coming up, after the missile strikes in Syria, what is next? Was it really mission accomplished, or is the situation about to spin out of control? Retired Major General Dave Fraser and Canada's former top spy Dick Fadden are here next. Stay right here with "Question Period".

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Document QUES000020180416ee4f00003


HD Feds have options to cut risk for Trans Mountain pipeline investors, says Carr
BY Mia Rabson
CR The Canadian Press 
WC 870 words
PD 13 April 2018
ET 14:37
SN The Canadian Press
SC CPR
LA English
CY (c) 2018 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

OTTAWA — Canada is considering several ways to reduce the financial risk for Kinder Morgan investors spooked by the uncertainty plaguing the planned Trans Mountain pipeline expansion, Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr said Friday as a high-level, make-or-break meeting loomed on the horizon.

The government is still examining its options, Carr said, but won't commit to a course of action before Sunday, when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau jets home from Peru for a hastily organized meeting in Ottawa with British Columbia Premier John Horgan and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley.

TD 

"What we're now faced with is to find ways to make sure there is more certainty than there is now," Carr said in an interview with The Canadian Press.

"One of the ways to make sure there is more certainty is to look at possible financial arrangements that would help de-risk the project."

Pipeline builder Kinder Morgan has halted all non-essential spending on the project until it gets assurances from Ottawa that the issues will be resolved. The federal government has until May 31 to respond.

Trudeau has put a lot of political eggs in the Trans Mountain basket, risking political capital among climate-change activists in search of middle ground that allows for pipeline construction alongside improved environmental safeguards.

Trudeau, who is currently in Peru for the Summit of the Americas, was originally supposed to fly to Paris directly from Lima on Sunday for meetings with French President Emmanuel Macron. Instead, he'll be back in the national capital in search of a resolution to an intractable — and politically perilous — dispute.

Carr refused to discuss the specific financial options available, other than to say there are many of them on the table and they're all being considered.

One of those options, however, is to buy a stake in the pipeline, something Notley has already said Alberta would be willing to do. Canada and Alberta could jointly buy the pipeline outright, or at least a significant stake in the project.

Another option is to provide a guaranteed source of revenue for private investors if the pipeline completion date misses the target for when returns on their investments were supposed to start flowing.

The company had targeted May 31 as the make-or-break deadline to start construction if the pipeline was to hit those investment targets. That date is now the drop-dead date Kinder Morgan has given Canada to prove the company should have the confidence to move forward.

Political strategist Robin Sears, a principal at Earnscliffe Strategy Group, said another option would be to increase spending on the environmental protection side, including on improved research into preventing and mitigating the impacts of a diluted bitumen spill.

"The company has not done what it needs to have done to satisfy the people of B.C. they have taken the steps necessary to protect the environment," said Sears.

Sears said the Trudeau government has an oceans protection plan on paper, but hasn't done much if anything to put it into action.

Carr was only prepared to say Sunday's meeting between Trudeau and the premiers would be a chance for the various sides to share their positions and try and talk things out — not necessarily a day when further action would be announced.

That, said Sears, would be a bad political move.

"If they come out of that meeting on Sunday and (Trudeau) says, 'We've made good progress and I'm off to Paris,' it will cost them severely," he said.

University of British Columbia politics professor Kathryn Harrison said she doesn't know that there is a way for everyone to come out of Sunday's meeting with a win.

"They have drawn lines in the sand that are simply incompatible," said Harrison.

Trudeau and Carr have spent more than two years accusing the former Conservative government of themselves failing to build pipelines because they stacked the deck against environmental concerns, failing in the process to get the social license necessary to allow the projects to proceed.

The Liberals introduced new review processes that accounted for things like the potential greenhouse gas emissions resulting from increased oil flows. The National Energy Board's 2016 approval of Trans Mountain required monitoring and upstream emissions offsets related to construction.

But environmental concerns remain — including the risk of higher emissions from increased oilsands production and the environmental impact of a spill. As a result, environmentalists who helped get Trudeau elected are now doubting his commitment to the cause.

Harrison said Trudeau has staked a claim on being able to reconcile both interests, offering up the pipeline — and the resulting ability to get resources to market — as a quid pro quo to get provincial and stakeholder support for a carbon price and environmental investments.

"That was the compromise and they got pretty far with it," Harrison said, noting all provinces but Saskatchewan signed onto the climate change framework.

"We're at that point now where the trains are colliding. This is a moment of truth for Canada and a country that relies heavily on producing fossil fuels."


IN 
i1 : Energy

NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | caon : Ontario | cabc : British Columbia | caab : Alberta | ottaw : Ottawa | namz : North America

IPD 
National | Business | Prairies/BC | Oil&Gas | Environment | Politics

PUB 
The Canadian Press

AN 
Document CPR0000020180413ee4d00itu


SE Columnists
HD MacDougall: Trudeau's in trouble on the pipeline battle
WC 1012 words
PD 13 April 2018
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2018 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

"The Trans Mountain expansion will be built."

With the nation mourning Humboldt's loss, pecking out an obstinate tweet about an oil pipeline buried in political grief wasn't at the top of Justin Trudeau's to-do list, yet out the above twittered ahead of the prime minister joining members of the shattered prairie community for last Sunday's vigil.

TD 

Canada is a country of the rule of law, and the federal government will act in the national interest. Access to world markets for Canadian resources is a core national interest. The Trans Mountain expansion will be built. https://t.co/97vvScpvOo[https://t.co/97vvScpvOo]( https://t.co/97vvScpvOo[https://t.co/97vvScpvOo] )

- Justin Trudeau (@JustinTrudeau) April 9, 2018( https://twitter.com/JustinTrudeau/status/983137468047347712?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw[https://twitter.com/JustinTrudeau/status/983137468047347712?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw] )

Welcome to government, where events never pause and most days are an endless series of bad and worse choices. Trudeau is certainly down to bad and worse on the question of Kinder Morgan's crown jewel, which happens to double as his fig-leaf on oil and gas policy.

Trudeau the green carbon-taxer might really, really (really) want this singular pipeline built, but if the company building it is now wavering, and the Green party dependent NDP premier of the province through which it must pass hasn't yet found a body he won't chuck in front of it, at what point do you call a spade no spade and concede the Earth will not be moving?

Perhaps fearing for its economic and constitutional credibility, the answer from Team Trudeau is a ringing "not now, not ever."

"We are determined to see (Trans Mountain) built," Trudeau has told reporters. "It is in the national interest. It doesn't make any sense for us to continue to have a $15-billion discount on our oil resources because we are trapped with an American market. We need to get our resources to new markets."

Indeed. The same words could have - and did - come out of Stephen Harper's mouth. Trudeau now has to bell the cat.

Federal Green Party Leader Elizabeth May, centre, is arrested by RCMP officers after joining protesters outside Kinder Morgan's facility in Burnaby, B.C., on March 23, 2018.

It wasn't meant to be this way. Harper's confrontational "cram-them-down-your-throats" pipeline policy was to be replaced with Trudeau's more charismatic approach that would accrue the "social license" needed to grease construction, a canard that happens to be, despite the environmental hysteria, the only fauna killed to date along the pipeline's route.

To frame the debate as pro-economy versus pro-environment is to miss the point.

What Trans Mountain ultimately proves is the past 20 years of debate in Canada has split people into two irreconcilable camps: pro-oil and anti-oil. Preening at climate summits and taxing carbon won't make exporting oil kosher to those who are resolutely opposed. Over their dead bodies is the message being passed to Trudeau at the minute. It's not a question of law, it's a matter of will.

Giddy though the opposition parties might be, now is not the time for them to revel in Trudeau's mire. Seeing your opponent hoist with his own petard is satisfying, but if the pipeline really is in Canada's national interest - and it is - the opposition should offer some constructive suggestions along with any withering scorn.

Given the rather shouty and petty state of modern politics, this won't happen.

The partisan urge to nanny-nanny-boo-boo is too strong and besides, Conservatives will say, the Liberals didn't exactly lift a finger of support in opposition before assuming office and turning the matter into a constitutional crisis. Further disincentivizing bipartisan efforts is the Trudeau carbon tax, a big part of the government's social license play that is not particularly well-read by any capital-C Conservative.

Alberta Premier Rachel Notley talks to cabinet members about the Kinder Morgan pipeline expansion, in Edmonton on Monday, April 9, 2018.

Here, Trudeau shoulders a good chunk of the blame. For all his talk of kumbaya, Trudeau's Pan Canadian Framework for Clean Energy and Climate Change - with its plan for carbon "pricing" - was effectively crammed down provincial throats. And with Rachel Notley and Kathleen Wynne's governments now in severe financial distress, voters there and across Canada will surely begin to wonder why the hell they're on the road to higher taxes if those uppity British Columbians aren't holding up their end of the social-license bargain.

This is where federal NDP leader Jagmeet Singh should have a useful intervention to make, given it's his provincial brethren on opposite sides of the Kinder Morgan dispute. But to hope for substance from Singh is to wish for unicorns. Singh has done the easy thing and sided with B.C. and its brighter federal electoral prospects.

Where does this leave Trans Mountain? Shorn of friends and solutions, but all is not yet lost.

The government can, and should, re-assert its constitutional right to build the pipeline. And yes, the feds can join Alberta in slapping down money and insurance guarantees. But that's only half the battle.

Protesters chant as they wait for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's arrival to meet with members of the Canadian Coast Guard to discuss marine safety and spill prevention, in Victoria on Thursday, April 5, 2018.

If the communities along the pipeline route remain ready to obstruct its construction it's going to take a lot more than bucks and words to clear the way. Even the stern words of a judge urging protesters out of the way might not do the trick. What then?

Do the sunny ways of Trudeau the son even allow for a hint of the army steel flashed by his father? Do we just ... watch him?

Andrew MacDougall is a London-based communications consultant and ex-director of communications to former prime minister Stephen Harper.


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
trans,mountain,expansion,built,nation,mourning

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020180413ee4d0030g


SE Opinion
HD Trudeau stuck in a pipeline box that he built himself
BY tharper@thestar.ca
WC 821 words
PD 12 April 2018
SN The Hamilton Spectator
SC HMSP
LA English
CY Copyright (c) 2018 The Hamilton Spectator.

LP 

Sometimes leadership means recognizing that train in the distance is headed straight at you and doing something about it before you are forced to jump out of the way.

For Justin Trudeau, the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion train has been bearing down on him and his government for close to a year, yet it has been allowed to become a crisis worthy of an extraordinary cabinet meeting and an interprovincial fight that should concern all Canadians.

TD 

For all the prime minister's talk about how the economy and the environment go hand-in-hand, sometimes they become detached and action is needed, not a continuation of a Goldilocks not-too-hot, not-too-cold mantra that works as a sound bite, but not always as policy.

Trudeau has allowed himself to be held hostage by a Texas-based energy corporation so tone deaf it issued an ultimatum on the project as this nation was mourning the Humboldt Broncos tragedy in Saskatchewan, and a rookie premier who signalled a year ago he would do exactly what he is doing today.

John Horgan is defending the British Columbia coast against increased tanker traffic, and whether or not one believes he has the right to hold up a project Trudeau has declared to be in the "national interest," he is doing precisely what he promised he would do if elected.

Immediately after his election there was rampant speculation that he would try to run out the clock to make the entire pipeline twinning project unpalatable to Kinder Morgan.

So here we are, a defining moment for the Trudeau government, with the clock ticking; a defining moment which Trudeau has largely brought upon himself.

Trudeau watched as Horgan and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley ratcheted up a trade war and Kinder Morgan should not have shocked anyone when it finally decided it couldn't continue to pour money into a project that has been continually stalled.

The Liberals, having already killed the Northern Gateway pipeline, watched Energy East die and their grand bargain with Notley rested solely with the Trans Mountain project.

Trudeau needed Notley and her environmental initiative to sell his national climate change plan. Notley needed a pipeline win as her quid pro quo, a lifeline which could win her re-election.

That grand plan is falling apart. With Jason Kenney waiting in the wings in Alberta and Doug Ford looking covetously at Queen's Park, that national plan faces further peril.

It is important to remember how a campaigning Trudeau promised to deal with pipelines and other resource development compared to where he stood Tuesday.

On "social license" the Liberal platform read: "While governments grant permits for resource development, only communities can grant permission."

That was modified a year into the mandate with a more broad definition that dealt with consultation and dropped any reference to permission.

Also, from the 2015 platform was a promise to Indigenous Canadians that they would be full partners on resource projects: "This will ensure on project reviews and assessments, the Crown is fully executing its consultation, accommodation and consent obligations, in accordance with its constitutional and international human rights obligations, including Aboriginal and treaty rights and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples."

The Conservative opposition does itself no favours as it takes aim at Trudeau. Conservative MPs have been hit by a collective amnesia that makes them forget 10 years of Stephen Harper championing various pipelines accomplished nothing more than irritating official Washington and an infamous Harper declaration that Obama's approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, was a "no-brainer."

When Harper okayed the Northern Gateway pipeline, no one from his government would stand in front of a camera to back the decision. It was left to wither until Trudeau mercifully killed it.

With two NDP governments at war, federal leader Jagmeet Singh has effectively gone to ground, refusing to stand up to either Notley or Horgan.

Trudeau's tool box remains more formidable than Horgan's and federal action should win the day. This is a federal project that can't be held up by a province.

But to get there, Trudeau is going to have to force an unpopular pipeline expansion by bulldozing it past a provincial government, Indigenous leaders and protesters.

Trudeau will expend much more than political capital. He will have his green bona fides shattered.

And he still might end up having to deal with Kenney and Ford in 2019.

A plan that looked so sound on paper has fallen apart on the ground.

Tim Harper is a former Star reporter who is a current freelance columnist based in Toronto. Follow him on Twitter: @nutgraf1


ART 
For Justin Trudeau, the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion train has been bearing down on him and his government for close to a year, writes Tim Harper

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

PUB 
Toronto Star Newspapers Limited

AN 
Document HMSP000020180412ee4c000e8


HD Trans Mountain Dispute
WC 966 words
PD 11 April 2018
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: And we expect that premiers meeting with the finance minister to wrap up in the next while, and we'll bring Bill Morneau's response when it happens. In the meantime, let's bring in the lead minister on the pipeline file. And Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr joins us from Winnipeg. Minister Carr, I appreciate you can't break cabinet confidence, but time is ticking away. You huddled with your colleagues yesterday to come up with a Trans Mountain pipeline rescue plan. What's emerged from those discussions beyond the revelation that all options are still on the table?

TD 

JIM CARR (Natural Resources Minister): Well, for Canadians to know that the government is 100 percent behind the construction of this pipeline. It's not a question of whether it will be built or not, it's the question of how. We're looking at financial and regulatory options that are available to us. Legal options too. We're certainly keen to have conversations with willing partners, and that would be the government of Alberta, it would be Kinder Morgan, and one can maybe even hope the government of British Columbia. I don't know if that's going to happen because most of all they have been sending out cloudy signals and trying to create a climate of uncertainty, which is the last thing our proponent wants. This is a pipeline as you know that's in federal jurisdiction, and we believe we have the legal authority, and we have even as important as that, we believe we have the good argument that most Canadians will understand about why it should be built.

MARTIN: Are you ready for what's coming, though? You know you're going to encounter very strong protests as construction moves ahead. You know you're coming against a province that is going to fight you tooth and nail in the courts and in any other way it can. You're saying that no matter what happens, no matter what obstacles go up before you, that pipeline is going through?

CARR: I'm saying that people are allowed to protest. It's what makes us special as a nation, as long as they protest legally. If they don't, and we have seen it, people will get arrested. That's the way the system works. It's the rule of law. And they're free to protest if they disagree with the government. We believe that we have the jurisdiction that has been proven time and time again by the courts, including the Supreme Court of Canada. So we have the jurisdiction, we think we've got the good arguments, and we have the determination to see the pipeline built.

MARTIN: But, but your prime minister, our prime minister always said we need the, quote, "social license" to move these through. Do you have that as well?

CARR: We consulted British Columbians and Canadians in a way that had never been done before. After the decision in the Northern Gateway case we knew we had to do a lot better than the Harper government had done, so we asked an expert panel to go up and down the line. They did. Tens of thousands of people weighed in, including British Columbians, and we believe that it was a very thorough process that gave us what we believe to be all of the good arguments for families, for the Canadian economy, for the expansion of export markets, for a $1.5 billion investment in the ocean protection plan. We think that the elements of the good decision were there, and we made it.

MARTIN: Just make sure, just to make this interview a little different from the one Monday, I want to ask you a couple questions if I can. Is the withholding of BC transfer payments as advocated by Alberta's Jason Kenney, is that an option?

CARR: You know we're not looking to ratchet up rhetoric here. We're making the arguments of why we think this is good for the country, and we're looking at all kinds of options that will make it clear to British Columbia and to all of Canada that the federal government is determined to see this pipeline built.

MARTIN: Well, withholding transfer payments would make it very clear to British Columbians what you're up against. Just asking if that's one of the options that you've got on the table?

CARR: You know, don, I've said, yeah, you know, we've been I think pretty clear about the buckets of options that are available to us and that we're considering carefully, and financial and regulatory are two of them. So we'll see how things develop over time, but the message, the clear message is that this pipeline is good for the Canadian economy and it is good for Canadian families.

MARTIN: We got that. Quick final point. Jagmeet Singh, the NDP leader, comes out today and says his game plan is to send this to the Supreme Court for some sort of reference, joint reference. Is that an option? Do you think that's a good idea, or is that something you're not even considering at this time?

CARR: I think that Mr. Singh constructively could do the country a favour if he called a meeting with the two NDP premiers of British Columbia and Alberta to see if he can't help broker a national unity consensus in his own party. And that consensus would be this is good for Canada.

MARTIN: All right. I'll say at this time go Jets go tonight. Thank you, Minister, appreciate you joining us.

CARR: Thank you! My pleasure.


NS
