  (4)        These are unrisked contingent resources that do not account for the chance of development which is defined as the probability of a project being commercially viable. Quantifying the chance of development requires consideration of both economic contingencies and other contingencies, such as legal, regulatory, market access, political, social license, internal and external approvals and commitment to project finance and development timing. As many of these factors are extremely difficult to quantify, the chance of development is uncertain and must be used with caution. The chance of development was estimated to be 80 percent for the Crude Oil and 5 percent for the Natural Gas.    
  
  (5)        The contingent resources are sub-classified as "development unclarified" with an "undetermined" economic status.    
 

The contingent resources represent the likely recoverable volumes associated with further phases of development after Phase 1. These are considered to be contingent resources rather than reserves due to the uncertainty over the future development plan which will depend in part on Phase 1 production performance and the heavy oil extended well test planned for the second half of 2018

Prospective resources have not been re-evaluated since December 31, 2013.

The Atrush Block is operated by the Abu Dhabi National Energy Company PJSC ("TAQA") and is held 39.9% by TAQA, 25% by the Kurdistan Regional Government ("KRG"), 20.1% by ShaMaran Petroleum Corp, through its wholly owned subsidiary General Exploration Partners, Inc. ("GEP") and 15% by Marathon Oil KDV B.V., (a wholly owned subsidiary of Marathon Oil Corporation (NYSE: MRO)). Atrush reserves and resource estimates presented represent solely the view of ShaMaran and its experts.

OTHER

This information in this release is subject to the disclosure requirements of ShaMaran Petroleum Corp. under the EU Market Abuse Regulation and the Swedish Securities Market Act. This information was publicly communicated on February 15, 2018 at 2:30 p.m. Vancouver time.

ABOUT SHAMARAN

ShaMaran Petroleum Corp. is a Kurdistan focused oil development and exploration company with a 20.1% direct interest in the Atrush oil discovery. The Atrush Block is currently undergoing an appraisal and development campaign. 

ShaMaran is a Canadian oil and gas company listed on the TSX Venture Exchange and the NASDAQ First North Exchange (Stockholm) under the symbol "SNM". Neither the TSX Venture Exchange nor its Regulation Services Provider (as that term is defined in the policies of the TSX Venture Exchange) accepts responsibility for the adequacy or accuracy of this release. Pareto Securities AB is the Company's Certified Advisor on NASDAQ First North.

FORWARD LOOKING STATEMENTS

This news release contains statements and information about expected or anticipated future events and financial results that are forward-looking in nature and, as a result, are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, such as legal and political risk, civil unrest, general economic, market and business conditions, the regulatory process and actions, technical issues, new legislation, competitive and general economic factors and conditions, the uncertainties resulting from potential delays or changes in plans, the occurrence of unexpected events and management's capacity to execute and implement its future plans. Any statements that are contained in this news release that are not statements of historical fact may be deemed to be forward-looking information. Forward-looking information typically contains statements with words such as "may", "will", "should", "expect", "intend", "plan", "anticipate", "believe", "estimate", "projects", "potential", "scheduled", "forecast", "outlook", "budget" or the negative of those terms or similar words suggesting future outcomes. The Company cautions readers regarding the reliance placed by them on forward‐looking information as by its nature, it is based on current expectations regarding future events that involve a number of assumptions, inherent risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by the Company.

Actual results may differ materially from those projected by management. Further, any forward-looking information is made only as of a certain date and the Company undertakes no obligation to update any forward-looking information or statements to reflect events or circumstances after the date on which such statement is made or reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events, except as may be required by applicable securities laws. New factors emerge from time to time, and it is not possible for management of the Company to predict all of these factors and to assess in advance the impact of each such factor on the Company's business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking information.

Reserves and resources: ShaMaran Petroleum Corp.'s reserve and contingent resource estimates are as at December 31, 2017, and have been prepared and audited in accordance with National Instrument 51-101 Standards of Disclosure for Oil and Gas Activities ("NI 51-101") and the Canadian Oil and Gas Evaluation Handbook ("COGE Handbook"). Unless otherwise stated, all reserves estimates contained herein are the aggregate of "proved reserves" and "probable reserves", together also known as "2P reserves". Possible reserves are those additional reserves that are less certain to be recovered than probable reserves. There is a 10% probability that the quantities actually recovered will equal or exceed the sum of proved plus probable plus possible reserves.

Contingent resources: Contingent resources are those quantities of petroleum estimated, as of a given date, to be potentially recoverable from known accumulations using established technology or technology under development, but are not currently considered to be commercially recoverable due to one or more contingencies. Contingencies may include factors such as economic, legal, environmental, political and regulatory matters or a lack of markets. There is no certainty that it will be commercially viable for the Company to produce any portion of the contingent resources.

BOEs: BOEs may be misleading, particularly if used in isolation. A BOE conversion ratio of 6 Mcf per 1 Bbl is based on an energy equivalency conversion method primarily applicable at the burner tip and does not represent a value equivalency at the wellhead.

Neither the TSX Venture Exchange nor its Regulation Services Provider (as that term is defined in the policies of the TSX Venture Exchange) accepts responsibility for the adequacy or accuracy of this release.

araur : ShaMaran Petroleum Corp. | goldi : Goldcorp Inc

i1 : Energy | i13 : Crude Oil/Natural Gas Upstream Operations | iexplo : Natural Gas/Oil Exploration

npress : Press Releases | ncat : Content Types

cana : Canada | vancv : Vancouver | cabc : British Columbia | namz : North America

PUB 
Marketwire L.P. (Canada)

AN 
Document CCNWS00020180215ee2f0018h


SE Columnists
HD Breakenridge: Please, let's not talk of social license again
BY David Marsden, Calgary Herald
WC 718 words
PD 14 February 2018
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2018 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

Since boycotts are suddenly fashionable, perhaps now would be an ideal time to suggest we collectively abandon the phrase social license.

At a time when it's become of crucial importance to overcome opposition to Alberta's energy exports and the needed pipeline infrastructure, the phrase social license is confusing, cringe worthy, politically loaded and needlessly distracting. Both sides need to retire it.

TD 

In this instance, both sides, refers to the current Alberta government and its approach to energy projects and environmental regulations, and the opposition, who have been, and remain, skeptical of the government's approach.

Most everyone agrees that the amount of opposition to a proposed pipeline is directly correlated to the difficulty in seeing that project through to completion. Therefore, it would logically follow that we need to do as much as we can to overcome that opposition.

One could call that social license, perhaps, but the phrase has already lost most of whatever meaning it had.

The concept of social license was not invented in Alberta, but it would appear as though the government of former premier Alison Redford was the first to use it. A June 2012 statement of cabinet and caucus priorities, for example, notes the importance of "maintain(ing) the social license to develop resources."

Rachel Notley's government has used it, too, albeit sparingly. The premier's preface to the 2016 budget speaks of the need to "strengthen Alberta's social license."

Otherwise, though, you'd be hard-pressed to find many example of the premier or other members of her government using the phrase.

To some, the concept invokes almost a literal license of sorts - as though Notley is capable of establishing such rock solid progressive bona fides that she can wave her "social license" around like a sheriff's badge and immediately command the respect of pipeline opponents.

While Notley can certainly be faulted for pandering to environmental groups - and giving activists such as Tzeporah Berman positions of power and influence - she has never claimed to be capable of vanquishing all opposition to the oilsands or pipelines.

She deliberately sought to try and reassure environmentalists that her government wouldn't ignore their concerns, but it's unclear how much she has to show for that.

Hence, the new argument that Notley's social license has clearly failed. This is evidenced, it's argued, by the fact that opponents of the Trans Mountain pipeline have not backed down and now B.C. Premier John Horgan is angling to make trouble for the project.

What exactly has failed, though? Notley's government sold their climate leadership plan (i.e., their carbon tax) on the notion that it would make it easier for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to approve pipeline projects.

Given that Trudeau did indeed say yes to Trans Mountain - and even credited Notley's approach - it's hard to argue that approach has failed.

It may yet. Notley is going to have to sell the carbon tax in the next election, and if she doesn't have an answer to the question, "what do we have to show for it?," then she could be in big trouble.

Since the premier has explicitly linked her carbon tax to new pipelines, the demise of Trans Mountain would indeed be a failure for her. We'll have to wait and see.

There's also the argument that social license is a myth, which of course, depends on how you define it in the first place. That it quickly becomes impossible to confirm or discredit such a vague assertion is yet another reason to retire the phrase altogether.

It is not a myth to assert that Alberta needs to make the case for its energy industry and the needed capacity to get our product to market. It is not a myth to argue that we need to win over as many allies to our cause as possible.

People can disagree on how best to accomplish that or how to define success. Either way, we'll be better off if we never hear the phrase social license ever again.

Afternoons with Rob Breakenridge airs weekdays on 770 CHQR. rob.breakenridge@corusent.com( mailto:rob.breakenridge@corusent.com )


NS 
genv : Natural Environment | gcat : Political/General News

RE 
caab : Alberta | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
boycotts,suddenly,fashionable,perhaps,ideal,suggest

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020180214ee2e00565


HD View from the Hill
WC 2383 words
PD 7 February 2018
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: Welcome back. Our Wednesday trio of MPs spanning the party divide are here for their always respectful analysis of each other's flawed logic. Candice Bergen is the official opposition house leader, Tracey Ramsey NDP MP from lovely Essex, and Steve MacKinnon is a government parliamentary secretary of procurement. All right, welcome to you all.

TD 

STEVEN MACKINNON (Liberal – Quebec): Public services and procurement.

MARTIN: That too. If you want to buy something from the government, you got to go to Steve, basically.

MACKINNON: Well, no, no, no. Not quite. Not quite.

(LAUGHTER)

MARTIN: Let's talk about this pipeline feud. We spent a lot of time on it on the show already, but I find this a really intriguing story. I don't know which side the NDP is on. BC, Alberta, what's your position, Tracey? Help me understand it, because I couldn't figure it out from your leader today?

TRACEY RAMSEY (NDP – Ontario): Well Rachel Notley is doing the job that she's been elected to do, and she is the premier with the most advanced I would say climate change plan that we have in our country right now. And John Horgan is also doing the job that he's been elected to do. What we see in the NDP federally is that Justin Trudeau is not doing what he promised. He's broken a promise to Canadians about the process. He promised to have a new environmental assessment process. He promised to talk about social license. And what do we see in Nanaimo last week at the town hall with him is that people in BC do not feel that he has done that, and we federally know that he has not done that. This is a broken promise about something that he made a commitment to standing in BC repeatedly throughout the election campaign. So this really is on the prime minister because he's now approved a project in this broken process, and he's using a little bit of some addressing some of the very serious issues that exist around the ocean protection as blackmail now about this pipeline.

MARTIN: I'm trying to figure out where you are. Should the pipeline proceed, or should the pipeline be stopped? If you had to choose "A" or "B", which would it be?

RAMSEY: For myself, I'm not going to choose "A" or "B" because this is about the provinces coming to what is best for them, and it's also about the federal government stepping in and playing a role here. Let's start the assessment process over. If Justin Trudeau is so convinced that this assessment process is the right way to go, then restart the process.

MARTIN: They're going to do that tomorrow though aren't they? You're not starting the process over.

MACKINNON: We committed to indeed redo the environmental assessment process. It is flawed, and we will be announcing in the fullness of time.

MARTIN: Tomorrow anyway.

MACKINNON: Amendments to that process. Let's recap though. On Kinder Morgan, we had an enhanced process where we put a panel on top of prior NEB review of the panel. We had Aboriginal involvement. We had involvement of former prominent British Columbians.

MARTIN: But now we're at a stalemate.

MACKINNON: Well, no, we're not at a stalemate. In fact we are at the culmination. This project has been approved. We wish to see it through. It is in the national interest. All of those things have been determined, have been determined by a constitutionally valid process, and we're doing three things, Don. We know that we have to get alternative and diverse markets for our energy resources. We know that a lot of our prosperity depends on that. We also know that you don't have to decide between the environment and the economy, because we've put in place a national climate framework with a carbon tax. We've put in a national oceans protection plan, $1.5 billion.

MARTIN: One law.

MACKINNON: Well, no, these are important points.

MARTIN: Well what's Trudeau's next step is what I'm asking.

MACKINNON: These are important points to make. MARTIN: Jump in here.

CANDICE BERGEN (Conservative House Leader): Where is the prime minister? We are on the verge of what could be a crisis between two governments, two provincial governments. We also have a pipeline that has been approved that is in the best interests of Canadians. It's certainly in the best interests of jobs for Canadians. We need the prime minister. Where is he? He's travelling around the US right now. He's in California talking about diversity.

MARTIN: Chicago today, California tomorrow.

BERGEN: He should be in Canada. Sorry, excuse me. Oh, I just saw his itinerary. It was a speech on diversity tomorrow. He should be in Canada. He should be talking to the premier of British Columbia. He should be taking and asserting leadership on this. This is in the national interest. You know, we saw the last time the prime minister was too afraid to talk to a municipal leader, it was Denis Coderre who didn't like Energy East, and the prime minister refused to stand up for pipelines in general, certainly he didn't say anything about Energy East, and the Liberal policies killed Energy East. Here's the problem and the real risk. If this pipeline is delayed, if Trans Mountain is delayed for too long, at some point the proponents go, you know what, we're outta here. That is a very real possibility. We need leadership. We need the prime minister to get home and to do his job for Canadians.

MACKINNON: This project has been permitted. It is in the national interest, and it will proceed.

MARTIN: Okay. I don't want to go on. Mercedes Stephenson, our CTV superstar here, had a very interesting story last night that actually got some new traction in question period today. Basically there's a class-action suit that's going forward by potentially thousands of soldiers, male and female, mostly female, who are saying that they were sexually harassed, or discriminated against, or maybe even assaulted in some cases. This case, the legal department, the government's legal department is arguing that it doesn't have an obligation to provide a harassment-free work force for the individual. Steve, help me understand why you would argue that position, because it sounds like you ran away from it today.

MACKINNON: Two important points. First of all, let's remember operation honour, the chief of the defence staff, the minister. Certainly this culture, if I can call it that, has seemed to grow over time, and it is a major challenge for the Canadian Armed Forces. I think that's been acknowledged, and I think that that's the product of many years, and we're tackling that head-on. Dozens of people have been released from the forces, and there have been major consequences, so that work continues apace, and I think the minister and others deserve praise for that, and I'm sure my colleagues would agree. With respect to the court case, it was fairly clear that in a pleading, some of the government's lawyers put in a phrase that did not accurately capture how the government feels about its custodial requirements over members of the armed forces, and the prime minister made that very clear and is instructing the attorney general.

MARTIN: Speaking of that, let's hear what the prime minister had to say. This is what Justin Trudeau said earlier today.

JUSTIN TRUDEAU (Canadian Prime Minister): News this morning that there were concerns about what the Justice Department is arguing in a sexual harassment case around the military is something that is of concern to me, and I've asked the attorney general to follow up with the lawyers to make sure that we argue things that are consistent with this government's philosophy. Obviously what the lawyers have been arguing does not align with what my belief, or what this government believes.

MARTIN: I guess some people would say he's speaking one way in the court of public opinion and another way in a court of law.

BERGEN: This is another example, and there's just becoming such a long list of examples where the prime minister's actions don't line up with his words. The fact is the prime minister put together a committee of his own cabinet ministers, seven cabinet ministers, including the justice minister, to actually look at litigation and to put it through the political and the belief lens. His cabinet ministers, his minister of justice would have signed off on this. What this boils down to, and we see this in this government, where their words don't line up, and so the prime minister talks about creating a safe workplace, he talks about addressing sexual harassment, but when it's really, when it's tough, when he has to actually step up, and his government has to step up and do it, we see this argument, and his own cabinet would have signed off on it.

MARTIN: Tracey.

RAMSEY: This is a blow to the work that's been done over the past month and over the past week in a nonpartisan way inside the house. We've been having conversations about guaranteeing a harassment-free workplace, and then we have something like this come out where lawyers are essentially saying that our military does not deserve that. It's not something that they are entitled to. This is bizarre to have the lawyers come out, and I think that knowing that ministers have seen this, that they're aware of this, and then this to come forward, it does such a disservice to the great work that we're trying to do inside this house for all Canadians. It's unacceptable that people in our military are being told that they do not deserve a harassment-free workplace.

MARTIN: There's also been another bit of a backtrack today. The government did approve the sale of a bunch of Bell helicopters built just in Quebec to the Philippines. This is a country where human rights records and how they treat drug trafficking and that sort of thing has been a big conflict. So it was exposed, and now it sounds, Steve, if I'm not mistaking it, the government is going to reconsider this. Is that what we're talking about?

MACKINNON: Well, no. In fact we have not approved a sale of helicopters to the Philippines.

MARTIN: That's news to the Philippines.

MACKINNON: If such a sale occurred, it did not occur on our watch, and although we do diplomatically engage with Philippines, I know the minister when she was there raised human rights, or possible human rights violations that may have occurred in the Philippines, and obviously we want to ensure that Canadian equipment is not used in such ways, so the government of Canada will continue to watch this. But to be very clear, the government of Canada did not, the current government of Canada did not approve the sale of these helicopters.

MARTIN: Tracey.

RAMSEY: So here's this thing. This isn't about a permit, an export permit, because these were actually done through the defence department. So this is a government department that this has happened through, and it was a direct sale versus having an export permit. So I don't, I think that what's been identified to everyone is that we have a process that is full of holes. We have loopholes that we've created where we can have certain departments, an export permit here, different processes being applied. We have to stop exporting to countries with massive human rights violations. It's unacceptable to Canadians. Canadians do not want this to be on our reputation on the global stage, and the Liberals cannot hide behind saying that their government didn't do this. They have to overhaul the process. It's something that the NDP has been calling for, and we have to ensure that we know where our helicopters are going, when we have Duterte who's saying basically at one point he threw someone out of a helicopter. Like this is so egregious. It's very concerning.

MARTIN: It's a tough one, you know, because there's big economic impacts for these contracts.

BERGEN: Well here's the challenge. And I mean under a previous governments there is a process whereby these types of sales are looked at and either approved or denied. The problem is it creates a lot of jobs in Canada, and a lot of this equipment is going to be purchased from the UK, from Germany, from Australia, from other countries, and so, you know, for sure, if there are ways that we can tighten up and ensure that our equipment is not being misused, definitely, but I think it would be irresponsible to say that to our, it would be irresponsible to our aerospace industry, to a lot of industries in Canada that create a lot of jobs that we just won't sell anything anymore to a country that may not be in line with our human rights record, even though very big concerns definitely with what would be done with those helicopters, but it has to be looked at carefully and you can't throw the baby out with the bathwater.

MACKINNON: To be clear, Canada would never approve a sale where human rights violations were... MARTIN: Saudi Arabia?

MACKINNON: ...were preemptively anticipated.

MARTIN: You are late for a vote, you three, so I'm going to let you go, even though... BERGEN: Are we too boring for you, Don?

MARTIN: You're great. You got to vote. You're the house leader so you should probably be in the house.

BERGEN: Well that's right, I better get there.

MARTIN: All right, thank you all. We'll see you next week.

MACKINNON: Thanks, Don.

BERGEN: Thanks.

RAMSEY: Thanks.

Document ONHILL0020180213ee2700005


HD BC-Alberta Trade Dispute
WC 991 words
PD 7 February 2018
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: All right. Let's reality check all this with the president of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, Perrin Beatty joins me in the studio. Mr. Beatty, nice to have you as always. You've heard both sides now. Sounds like they're digging in. What do you make of it?

TD 

PERRIN BEATTY (Canadian Chamber of Commerce): It's time for the prime minister to get people together, say come, let us reason together. Let's have an understanding here about where we're going, that we're one country, not 13, that the rule of law is going to apply in Canada, and that we won't take each other's business communities hostage.

MARTIN: Yeah, but you tweeted earlier today that this is a fight between BC and the rest of Canada. Why did you say that?

BEATTY: Because it's being positioned today as if it's a fight between the people of British Columbia and the people of Alberta. It's not. It's between the government of British Columbia and Canada. It comes down to who we are as a country, the fact that we're one nation. It's the federal government that has the responsibility to define the national interests. So here's a project that's gone through all the regulatory procedures. The rule of law has been followed. There's been lengthy discussion of it. The decision has been made. All sorts of conditions have been set that have to be met by the project. It's moving ahead. And the government has declared it in the national interest. At some point you have to be able to decide and move ahead or else you simply have a stalemate.

MARTIN: All right, so rule of law must always trump social license. Is that what you're saying?

BEATTY: I think the rule of law is absolutely critical, and social license is a part of it. Without the rule of law, how do you achieve social licence? If it's simply going to be something made up as you go along, and somebody will be able to say, any premier, or any other elected official, I disagree so I'm going to throw out all of the process that's gone before, that doesn't work. Imagine if British Columbia were coming into confederation today. Part of the confederation deal was the building of the CPR. Imagine if Alberta was standing in the way and saying we won't allow the CPR to be built across the territory of Alberta to tie British Columbia to the rest of Canada. We wouldn't have stood for that for a second. Nor should we stand for any provincial government saying, after all of these discussions, we're going to stand in the way and prevent one of the provinces from getting its resources to market in a responsible way.

MARTIN: Now you've got a history with some politics in there. You at one point in time were a cabinet minister.

BEATTY: A long, long, you're showing your age.

MARTIN: But sometimes politics blasts on. And I'm wondering, if both of these leaders, both of these premiers have electoral survival at stake here. Horgan can't be seen as caving on the pipeline, and Rachel Notley can't exist for a second term without a pipeline. How do you bridge that gap? Is it talk, or do you let Trudeau run in there with the constitutional powers he has and just force the building of this thing?

BEATTY: I think that's where the federal government comes in. What you have is you have a political problem here with two premiers who are locked in, who are looking to their local interests, their provincial interests. In the case of the government of British Columbia, they are looking for survival there, because they have to secure their majority within the legislature. There has to be somebody outside of this to say, look, the national interest comes first. That's where the federal government comes in.

MARTIN: We've seen premiers conferences talk about knocking down barriers across provinces since I was a cub reporter, and I just sort of wonder, it seems to me the walls are getting higher than ever. Is the day ever going to happen where we actually have free trade amongst provinces, never mind with the United States government?

BEATTY: That was vision of the fathers of confederation. It will be terrible if the current generation of premiers were the fathers and mothers of deconfederation where we're building walls and petitioning Canada. The bizarre thing is we're actually making progress as it relates to NAFTA. We may very well find that we can take down some of the barriers that have been threatened between Canada and the US. Wouldn't it be just beyond ironic if at the same time as we were taking down international barriers, we were erecting them internally within Canada. It makes no sense whatsoever. And what definitely doesn't make sense is to take somebody else's business community hostage.

MARTIN: Good point. Trudeau is down there in the States trying to save NAFTA, but he might have to save interprovincial trade.

BEATTY: It's a, this is a case where charity begins at home, I think.

MARTIN: All right, Perrin, thanks for coming in. Appreciate that.

BEATTY: Thank you.

MARTIN: All right, "Power Play" always welcomes your views on this or any other topic. Please reach out to us through social media. You can go to us on Facebook, we got Twitter, we got Instagram, or you can contact us via email. Our address is powerplay@ctvnews.ca. Coming up, America first might trigger an Ontario blockade to business down there. The premier is up next. Please stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | ntra : Transcripts | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfce : C&E Exclusion Filter | nfcpex : C&E Executive News Filter | niwe : IWE Filter

RE 
cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

Document ONHILL0020180213ee2700003


HD Roundup 2018: AME’s Edie Thome on  BC’s mineral politics
WC 782 words
PD 6 February 2018
SN The Northern Miner
SC NMNR
LA English
CY Copyright 2018. The Northern Miner Group. All Rights Reseved.

LP 

VANCOUVER —The Association for Mineral Exploration’s (AME) Roundup conference in Vancouver serves as a bellwether for the mining industry as the first major technical event of the new year.

The most recent iteration featured the typical discussions on metal prices and markets,[http://www.northernminer.com/news/roundup-2018-osiskos-roosen-tackling-tough-markets/1003793360/]but it also marked the maiden mining voyage for B.C.’s newly elected, left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) and Green Party coalition government.

TD 

The NDP-led minority government’s stance on mining in the province remains untested.

[caption id="attachment_1003793754" align="alignright" width="306"] “We’ve said very clearly that we need federal and provincial mandates to dovetail together and they can’t be in conflict, or it just creates even more bureaucracy.”

Edie Thome

President, AME[/caption]

Premier John Horgan has been rhetorically supportive of the business, and held over pro-mining initiatives from the previous long-standing Liberal government, including its flow-through share tax framework and exploration credits; funding for Geoscience BC; and provincial sales tax breaks for electricity used at mine sites.

Meanwhile, B.C.’s Minister of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources Michelle Mungall is working with industry groups — including the AME — on the BC Mining Jobs Task Force.

Conversely, the NDP has taken a relatively combative stance on the oil industry in its approach to the Kinder Morgan (TSX: KML; NYSE: KMI) Trans-Mountain pipeline expansion.

It has also committed to the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP), which adds uncertainty to a permitting process that has been regularly criticized for inefficiency and redundancy.

“We had been operating under a stable government that had been in place for quite some time,” commented AME president and Edie Thome during an interview following the Roundup conference. “Now we have new ministers transitioning into leadership from the opposition. It looks like commodities might be firming up in 2018, so we’re very interested to see how the new government plans to integrate all of these mandates it’s outlined.”

Director of mineral development for the B.C. Ministry of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources, Gordon Clarke, revealed during the conference that mining in the province generated $9.8 billion in economic value in 2017.

The biggest earner for B.C. was metallurgical coal, which accounted for 61% of that total. The province is also Canada’s largest producer of copper, which generated $2.25 billion.

“We need to look at addressing some of the regulatory issues and making B.C. a top destination for investment capital,” Thome continued. “There are a number of initiatives that show up in multiple ministry mandate letters under the umbrella of the [UN Declaration]. There’s industry concern about stacking these things and effectively getting more bureaucratic versus getting any value out of it. We’ve made the deputy ministers aware of that.”

[caption id="attachment_1003778101" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Teck Resources’ Highland Valley copper-molybdenum mine, 50 km southwest of Kamloops, British Columbia. Credit: Teck Resources.[/caption]

The need for regulatory certainty is especially pressing for AME’s members, which includes more than 6,000 people employed in the mineral exploration industry. AME reported $247 million in exploration spending in B.C. last year. The figure is higher than the $205 million spent in 2016, but well below the nearly $700 million spent in 2011–2012.

“When you look at the hard factors, like having a mining code and anti-corruption, B.C. is clearly near the top,” Thome said. “But when we start talking about the timing on regulatory permitting, social license, and indigenous inclusion it becomes much harder. So we need to tackle these issues and ease any concerns financial investors might have in that regard.”

The national regulatory landscape hasn’t provided much more clarity due to a pending review of Canadian environmental assessment processes from the Liberal-led federal government. Kim Rudd, parliamentary secretary to the minister of Natural Resources Canada, was also in attendance at Roundup, but provided little details on potential changes outside of a retread of the “one project, one assessment” slogan previously leveraged by the Harper government in 2012.

Federal Environment and Climate Change Minister Catherine McKenna introduced a bill in early February to enact the Impact Assessment Actand the Canadian Energy Regulator Act, and amend the Navigation Protection Act.

“There are a number of overlapping issues between the federal and provincial governments, and we’ll certainly be engaging in that process,” Thome said. “We’ve said very clearly that we need federal and provincial mandates to dovetail together and they can’t be in conflict, or it just creates even more bureaucracy.”


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cabc : British Columbia | vancv : Vancouver | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
News]]> | Regulatory | Issues]]> | Roundup | 2018]]>

PUB 
The Northern Miner Group

AN 
Document NMNR000020180215ee260005r


HD Roundup 2018: AME's Thome on BC's mineral politics
WC 769 words
PD 6 February 2018
SN The Northern Miner
SC NMNR
LA English
CY Copyright 2018. The Northern Miner Group. All Rights Reseved.

LP 

VANCOUVER —The Association for Mineral Exploration’s (AME) Roundup conference in Vancouver serves as a bellwether for the mining industry as the first major technical event of the new year.

The most-recent iteration featured the typical discussions on metal prices and markets[http://www.northernminer.com/news/roundup-2018-osiskos-roosen-tackling-tough-markets/1003793360/], but it was also marked the maiden mining voyage for British Columbia's newly-elected, left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) and Green Party coalition government.

TD 

The NDP-led minority government's stance on mining in the province remains untested.

Premier John Horgan has been rhetorically supportive of the business, and held over pro-mining initiatives from the previous long-standing Liberal government, including the flow-through share tax framework and exploration credits; funding for Geoscience BC; and provincial sales tax (PST) breaks for electricity used at mine sites.

[caption id="attachment_1003793754" align="alignright" width="306"] AME president and CEO Edie Thome. Credit: The Association for Mineral Exploration.[/caption]

Meanwhile, B.C.'s Minister of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources Michelle Mungall is working with industry groups — including the AME — on the BC Mining Jobs Task Force.

Conversely, the NDP has taken a relatively combative stance on the oil industry in its approach to the Kinder Morgan (TSX: KML; NYSE: KMI) Trans-Mountain pipeline expansion.

It has also committed to the United Nations (UN) Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP), which adds uncertainty to a permitting process that has been regularly criticized for inefficiency and redundancy.

"We had been operating under a stable government that had been in place for quite some time," commented AME president and Edie Thome during an interview following the Roundup conference. "Now we have new ministers transitioning into leadership from the opposition. It looks like commodities might be firming up in 2018, so we're very interested to see how the new government plans to integrate all of these mandates its outlined."

Director of mineral development for the B.C. Ministry of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources, Gordon Clarke, revealed during the conference that mining in the province generated $9.8 billion in economic value in 2017.

[caption id="attachment_1003778101" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Teck Resources’ Highland Valley copper-molybdenum mine, 50 km southwest of Kamloops, British Columbia. Credit: Teck Resources.[/caption]

The biggest earner for B.C. was metallurgical coal, which accounted for roughly 61% of that total. The province is also Canada's largest producer of copper, which generated around $2.25 billion.

"We need to look at addressing some of the regulatory issues and making B.C. a top destination for investment capital," Thome continued. "There are a number of initiatives that show up in multiple ministry mandate letters under the umbrella of the [UN Declaration]. There's industry concern about stacking these things and effectively getting more bureaucratic versus getting any value out of it. We've made the deputy ministers aware of that."

The need for regulatory certainty is especially pressing for AME's members, which includes more than 6,000 people employed in the mineral exploration industry. AME reported around $247 million in exploration spending in B.C. last year. The investment marked a modest improvement on the $205 million spent in 2016, but remains well below the nearly $700 million spent in 2011-12.

"When you look at the hard factors, like having a mining code and anti-corruption, B.C. is clearly near the top," Thome said. "But when we start talking about the timing on regulatory permitting, social license, and indigenous inclusion it becomes much harder. So we need to tackle these issues and ease any concerns financial investors might have in that regard."

The national regulatory landscape hasn't provided much more clarity due to a pending review of Canadian environmental assessment processes from the Liberal-led federal government. Kim Rudd, parliamentary secretary to the minister of Natural Resources Canada, was also in attendance at Roundup, but provided little details on potential changes outside of a retread of the "one project, one assessment" slogan previously leveraged by the Harper government in 2012.

Federal Environment Minister Catherine McKenna is expected to table a bill in early February to enact the Impact Assessment Actand the Canadian Energy Regulator Act, and amend the Navigation Protection Act.

"There are a number of overlapping issues between the federal and provincial governments, and we'll certainly be engaging in that process," Thome said. "We've said very clearly that we need to federal and provincial mandates to dovetail together and they can't be in conflict, or it just creates even more bureaucracy."


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | vancv : Vancouver | namz : North America

IPD 
News]]> | Regulatory | Issues]]> | Roundup | 2018]]>

PUB 
The Northern Miner Group

AN 
Document NMNR000020180206ee260002t


HD The Scrum Part II
WC 1433 words
PD 4 February 2018
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2018 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): EVAN SOLOMON

TD 

EVAN SOLOMON: Well, when the cranes pulled down the statue of the military officer Edward Cornwallis, the so-called modern founder of Halifax back in 1749, the controversy continued. Cornwallis, after all, was the author of the so-called scalping proclamation, which offered a bounty to anyone who killed a Mi'kmaq First Nation. But on the week when the words of the national anthem are actually changed to be more gender neutral, we've gone from "all of thy sons command" to "all of us command." Some are saying history is being erased. Others are saying, it's about time. To talk about this and the big pipeline debate going on, the scrum is back. Of course Laura, Joyce and Craig are here. As always, and our special guest is professor Pam Palmater, chair in indigenous governance at Ryerson University, and a Mi'kmaq activist. She joins us from Toronto. Great to have everyone here and Pam, let me start with you and then start with this thing, taking down the statue of Cornwallis, right thing to do?

PAM PALMATER (Indigenous Activist): Oh, of course it's the right thing to do, and it's long overdue. I mean, we're talking about someone who symbolized genocide, the outright, you know, paid bounty to murder people. And that's not something that should be normalized or celebrated or memorialized. Now that taking down his statue doesn't remove what he did or didn't do for Halifax and the history books. That will all still be there. But it's a necessary part of de-colonizing, reconciliation and really stopping this normalization of violence against indigenous people, which was very specific and targeted the Mi'kmaq people.

SOLOMON: Laura, look, I have no problem with that because the scalping proclamation is so clearly something vile. On the other hand, there are those that say there's what's called presentism, judging people in the 1740s by standards in 2018, and that's just not fair. What do, how, what's the balance there?

LAURA STONE (The Globe and Mail): Yeah, no, to me, this is all about context. You know, I agree with Pam that you can't be erasing Cornwallis' legend at all, like his history. We need to put what he did in context of what's acceptable now. It's a teachable moment. So maybe you take down a statue that many people think revered him, but you put that in a museum, which I understand they may be doing.

SOLOMON: The Mi'kmaq want him in a...

STONE: ...want him in a museum with an explanation of what happened, which gives the full story of who he was.

CRAIG OLIVER (CTV News): In the 17th and 18th century even, it was not a standard to put a price on people's heads who had done nothing...

PALMATER: Exactly.

OLIVER: ...and murder them. So even by the standards of those days, an officer, and a gentleman, did not go around putting a price on people to kill, to have them killed.

JOYCE NAPIER (CTV News): Why not put a plaque? Why not remind people what this man did, instead of trying to erase the past, we can't. It's full of contradictions. It's full of blood. That is who we are. Then put a plaque, and say shame, right?

SOLOMON: Instead of taking it down.

NAPIER: We have Holocaust memorials, right? We are not glorifying the holocaust. We are teaching people that this should never happen again.

PALMATER: You can't have both ways. You can't have your cake and eat it, too. You don't get to memorialize and celebrate and commemorate someone who committed genocide, and then just put a little plaque and say, but you know, they shouldn't do it again. Look at Germany, they totally de-Nazified Germany, and it was against the will of the people, and it took many decades for the people of Germany to understand why they had to remove statues and flags and everything else. Because it's about changing minds and hearts. And you will never do that so long as they are memorialized.

SOLOMON: Okay, we just, I want to move to this other issue, which is pipeline debates. And Laura, let me just start with you because we had Rachel Notley on. Look, Rachel Notley's election depends on, she's got to build a pipeline. She's the (inaudible). But on the other hand, Premier Horgan in BC, his election depends on not building a pipeline. And Justin Trudeau's stuck in the middle. What does Trudeau do here with this pipeline?

STONE: Well, I think he has to put his money where his mouth is. He says that this pipeline is going to get built. He's been saying this in town halls across the country. So now, he's going to be painted into a corner by the Conservatives to promise, absolutely, to show how his government is going to do this. He can't just have all these talking points now where he says, it's going to get built without any action. So, he's going to be under a lot of pressure to interfere in this fight.

SOLOMON: Right.

OLIVER: Because this is not just a challenge from BC to Alberta. It's also a challenge on federal power. And he represents that power, or else he weakens the credibility of his own government. Every legal case, judges have said the federal government has total, complete jurisdiction over the building of these pipelines. Don't get in the way. So, Trudeau has to push that and he may even have to go nuclear. He may have to use the declaration clause in section 92 of the Constitution, which takes away jurisdiction from provincial cities and the province, and gives it to his own government.

SOLOMON: He could. I don't know if he will. Joyce, where do you think he is on this?

NAPIER: I'm with Laura, you know? As soon as Horgan came to power, I remember, we were at the G7. We asked him that question. Will you move on? Will you push ahead with the pipeline? And he said, yes. It was unequivocal. So, he said yes. Put your money where your mouth is, and now act.

SOLOMON: One of the things he's also signed off on is what's called the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of Indigenous People, which means indigenous peoples have not, they don't just need their consultation, consent. And if there's indigenous people...

PALMATER: Exactly.

SOLOMON: ...in BC that don't want this, how does Justin Trudeau, who supposedly champions that, then champion that pipeline? What do you think he does?

PALMATER: Well, I don't think he can. I mean in these town halls, he has been championing this pipeline, as you know, environmentally friendly and needed for the country. But he also forgets how he got elected, and it was on the promise that he couldn't do any of these things without a community license, a social license where the people say yes, and he also said, fully recognizes the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, promises free prior and informed consent. And there is not consent. And he's also disregarding the Supreme Court of Canada in (inaudible) most recent Chilcotin case, which says Aboriginal title is exclusive, that's exclusive use management benefit, and there are many First Nations along that area that are going to make claims to Aboriginal title that say you simply can't do it without our consent. So he may be distracted by the provincial battle right now, but he's really forgetting how much power First Nations have.

SOLOMON: Pam Palmater, great to have you on the program. Real pleasure. And of course, Joyce Napier, always great to see Joyce. And Laura Stone and our great friend and mentor, Craig Oliver, and great to see you. The prime minister heads back to the United States on Wednesday, shuttling between Chicago, San Francisco and LA to pitch the benefits of free trade. Maybe he'll end up in Canada, eventually. And Olympians will go for gold by week's end, when the Winter Olympic kicks off in PyeongChang. For all of us here at "Question Period", whoa, have a great weekend. Thanks for watching. We'll see you back here in seven days.


CO 
rysnun : Ryerson University

cana : Canada | namz : North America

Bell Media Inc.

SE News
HD Can Trudeau afford to step back into grimy pipeline politics?
BY By CAMPBELL CLARK
CR Staff
WC 768 words
PD 1 February 2018
SN The Globe and Mail
SC GLOB
ED Ontario
PG A19
LA English
CY ©2018 The Globe and Mail Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Justin Trudeau has the jurisdiction to push back B.C.'s new threat to block the Trans Mountain pipeline, but does he have the will?

The Prime Minister hoped he had done the politics on pipelines in 2016, long before an election, balancing approval of an expansion of the pipeline to Burnaby, B.C., with a price on carbon and a climatechange agreement with provinces. But the mess is back, and that spells trouble for Mr. Trudeau.

TD 

British Columbia's NDP government, which depends on Green Party support to survive, announced a review of whether a bitumen spill could be properly cleaned up – and said it would regulate to block any increase the flow of bitumen through the province and onto tankers until that review is completed.

If this were just a jurisdictional fight between B.C. and Ottawa, it would be pretty easy for Mr. Trudeau to push back. B.C. has powers to regulate its environment, but approving pipelines, and the inter-provincial transportation of resources such as oil, is federal jurisdiction. The pipeline is supposed to meet provincial rules, but if B.C. is using them to frustrate the federal government's powers, it would have a hard time making its case in court.

But this is politics. Mr. Trudeau has to worry that if he picks a fight with B.C., it shines the spotlight on his approval of the Trans Mountain pipeline. That just brings up a decision that is unpopular with environmentally conscious Liberal voters, and with some of the constituents of Liberalheld ridings in the Lower Mainland. The Liberals wanted the controversy to cool down, not fire up as the 2019 election gets closer.

While Alberta Premier Rachel Notley called an emergency cabinet meeting on Wednesday and threatened legal action if B.C. tries to prevent the flow of more bitumen, federal Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr was mum, standing pat on a terse statement he issued on Tuesday. That statement said the Liberal government stands by its approval of the pipeline – but did not warn B.C. it does not have the power to obstruct the decision.

Ms. Notley's government wants Ottawa to make a stronger statement. “Alberta also expects the federal government to stand up and defend the constitution and its significance to the economic stability of the country," Cheryl Oates, Ms. Notley's director of communications, said in an e-mail.

There were already significant court challenges filed by First Nations and 157 conditions that pipeline promoter Kinder Morgan Canada Ltd. had to meet. The B.C. government has every right to review whether it is really feasible to clean up a spill of diluted bitumen. But their right to apply environmental protections is likely to stop at Ottawa's power to approve pipelines. Among the plans, according to B.C.'s backgrounder, is to broaden its authority over marine affairs.

But Ottawa has the sole power to regulate the navigation and shipping of the oil tankers that would carry the diluted bitumen, said Dalhousie University law professor Aldo Chircop, a professor of maritime law at Dalhousie University.

At the moment, B.C. has not said just how it proposes to regulate to prevent an increase in the amount of bitumen that flows through the province, but almost any effective measure is likely to meet a pretty stiff challenge from those who insist it is Ottawa's jurisdiction.

Having jurisdiction does not help Mr. Trudeau with his political problem, though. He thought he had finessed the issue in 2016 by promising to balance approval of the pipeline with climate action. Mr. Trudeau and Ms. Notley argued that climate policy was supposed to help provide the “social license" for oil sands development and pipelines. Mr. Trudeau also got the government of former BC Liberal premier Christy Clark to buy in by pumping $1.5-billion into an ocean protection plan.

That neat piece of work is unravelling now. B.C. Premier John Horgan is already facing tension with his Green Party partner Andrew Weaver over approval of the Site C dam and apparent interest in liquefied natural gas projects. He has to talk tough on Trans Mountain.

Mr. Trudeau, meanwhile, cannot just ditch his promise to make sure Canadian resources get to market – that was the balance between development and environment he promised. But it is politically dangerous to act too tough with a B.C. government that argues it is protecting its citizens against environmental risks, especially as an election gets nearer.


NS
