Document ONHILL0020171129edbl00005


SE News
HD Thanks, Trump!
BY Lorne Gunter
CR Edmonton Sun
WC 648 words
PD 21 November 2017
SN The Edmonton Sun
SC EDMNTN
ED Final
PG A5
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 The Edmonton Sun

LP 

Donald Trump may have saved Rachel Notley's political hide.

Admittedly, an NDP win remains a real long shot in the 2019 election.

TD 

But for the NDP to have any shot, at least one major pipeline has to be under construction by the time the election is called in the spring of 2019.

A lot else has to be going right, too.

The price of oil has to continue its climb from where it is now (in the $55US range) to around $70US. The NDP have to reduce spending and begin to get their deficit under control. And tens of thousands of energy-sector workers have to be back working again.

Still, if the Alberta economy is humming when the election is called two years from now, there is an extremely narrow path to victory for the New Democrats.

Since Keystone XL (KXL) is the pipeline most likely to be under construction by 2019, Notley and the NPD owe their tiny sliver of hope to the U.S. president.

After all, it was Trump who agreed to give federal permits to the $8-billion pipeline project back in March. That reversed seven years of stalling and, finally, outright rejection by the Obama administration.

Sure, technically, it was Monday's approval by the Nebraska Public Service Commission that removed the last official hurdle to Keystone XL. But without Trump's approval first, the Nebraskans wouldn't even have made a decision.

A lot can still go wrong. TransCanada Corp. might decide not to go ahead with the 1,800-km extension of their existing Keystone line that would connect Alberta's oilsands with a pipeline hub in Cushing, Oklahoma.

When TransCanada cancelled the Energy East pipeline in October, it did so mostly because of environmental hurdles erected by Justin Trudeau's federal Liberal government. But to the extent that decision was economic, Keystone might prove to be equally uneconomic..

American courts might also side with environmentalists or Nebraska ranchers and issue injunctions against construction. Or protestors might block construction for weeks or months.

So, Keystone is far from a done deal just yet, although it remains the most likely major pipeline to actually get built.

It would be a shame though if Keystone helped Notley get re-elected. At the very best, her attitude towards the project has been lukewarm.

Our premier has held many positions on Keystone, but she has probably been opposed or indifferent more than she has been in favour.

When Notley and the NDP were in opposition before the May 2015 election, they were clearly against the pipeline.

Then during the campaign they sent mixed messages. Candidate Rachel Notley told the Edmonton Sun's editorial board she was in favour of Keystone. Later she told the CBC's Evan Solomon "we're against it."

Shortly after being sworn in as premier in May 2015, her federal NDP brethren came out staunchly against Keystone during the federal election. Notley refused to repudiate their stance.

When Barack Obama announced he was blocking Keystone in November 2015 - the same month the New Dems came out with their carbon tax and climate leadership plan - Notley refused to go to Washington to complain. She made it clear she'd rather Keystone didn't go ahead.

During the last U.S. presidential race, when Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton declared herself against Keystone, Notley said she and Clinton were on the same page.

After Trump was elected in November 2016, Notley refused once again to go to D.C. to lobby for Keystone saying it "was not key."

Now, I suppose, because her "social license" strategy has failed so miserably to get a single Canadian pipeline built, maybe that's why Notley has suddenly become such a big booster of Keystone.

Donald Trump has become Rachel Notley's last, best chance of a second term.


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
usa : United States | namz : North America

IPD 
Column | donald,trump,saved,rachel,political,admittedly

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document EDMNTN0020171121edbl0001p


SE The Write Stuff
HD  Rachel Notley's pipeline promotion tour a necessary step
BY Lorne Gunter
CR Postmedia Network
WC 637 words
PD 9 November 2017
SN Lacombe Globe
SC LACOMB
ED Final
PG A9
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Lacombe Globe

LP 

Later this month, Premier Rachel Notley will set off on a cross-Canada speaking tour to try to drum up support for pipelines, specifically for the already-approved Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain expansion.

It is an effort all Albertans can support, no matter what one thinks of her and her government.

TD 

We all need her rhetorical diplomacy to succeed. Our province's future prosperity needs Kinder Morgan to be built.

The Trans Mountain expansion is, essentially, the twinning of a pipeline that has operated safely since the 1950s.

It should be a slam dunk. It will take up almost no new land, cross no lakes or rivers it does not already cross. Its increased infringement on First Nations land will be negligible after construction is complete.

But that hasn't stopped environmentalists from going hysterical, particularly since the federal government approved the line almost exactly a year ago.

Environmental activists have threatened to fight the expansion in the courts and "in the woods," by which they mean demonstrations, sit-ins and, perhaps, even domestic terrorism.

Last week, Karen Mahon - who until June was one of Notley's closest advisors on oilsands development (Mahon wanted none) - and around 60 other "green" activists kayaked out into Vancouver's Burrard Inlet and chained their boats to a Kinder Morgan construction barge. Five, including Mahon, were arrested.

Another reason Notley has to be convincing on her cross-country speaking tour: For too long she has been far, far too cozy with eco-crazies who firmly believe all pipelines are the work of corporate devils, that they all must be stopped and that in their place Canada's economy can be powered by unicorn farts and fairy wands.

During her tour at the end of the month, Notley has to convince investors and voters, both, that her days of trying to get pipelines approved by currying favour with eco-activists through carbon taxes and emission caps are done.

What she calls "social license" has scared away investors and deepened and lengthened Alberta's recession.

This upcoming tour has to be her last gloves-on attempt to get a pipeline through to the coast. If this doesn't work, the gloves have to come off.

One of the "kayaktivists" arrested along with former Notley advisor Mahon - Liam Fox, a Simon Fraser University grad student - promised their stunt was only the beginning. "We don't have any other option. This pipeline has to be stopped."

Mahon herself pledged "you are going to see a rise of resistance like (B.C.) hasn't seen before."

And, of course, B.C.'s new NDP government is also pledged to stopping the line.

If activists are going to do "whatever it takes" to stop Kinder Morgan, Notley has to lead those who will do whatever it takes to get it built. There is no other natural leader for the propipeline effort. And the premier's national tour is the perfect place for her to prove she possesses that determination.

Because if she won't do whatever it takes, you can bet new UCP Leader Jason Kenney will.

And Alberta desperately needs pipelines (plural) built.

A study of the NDP's deficit spending and accumulating debt, released last week by the University of Calgary's school of public policy, shows how utterly unsustainable their spending spree is without more and more oil revenues.

For instance, while the NDP insists the province's debt will increase by $27.2 billion over the next three years, the U. of C. study says the reality could easily be closer to $38.9 billion - over 40 per cent above the Notley government's estimates.

That should give the premier incentive to do some impassioned talking on her tour.


RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

IPD 
News | later,month,premier,rachel,notley,speaking

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document LACOMB0020171109edb90000v


SE Canada
HD Jen Gerson: In a Calgary ballroom, a panel hashes out grim wake for the Energy East pipeline
BY Jen Gerson
WC 1178 words
PD 9 November 2017
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

CALGARY - In an ornate ballroom in one of downtown Calgary's few Edwardian hotels, hundreds of dark-suited men and women gathered over lunch Tuesday to hash out one of the questions festering at the heart of Alberta's politics: What really happened to Energy East?

The TransCanada pipeline was intended to be a win-win project: Alberta would gain access to tidewater for its beleaguered bitumen; oil would travel to a refinery on Canada's east coast; resources would stay in the country. But in October the company killed it, inspiring interprovincial rancour and darkening the province's increasingly sour mood.

TD 

In a letter to the National Energy Board explaining its decision, the company cited "delays resulting from the regulatory process," among other obstacles. Andrew Leach, a professor of energy policy at the University of Alberta and one of the architects of Alberta's climate change policy, was among the loudest voices crying foul over TransCanada's implication. Canning Energy East was a reasonable business decision inspired by low oil prices, reduced oilsands production forecasts and the imminent approval of Keystone XL, Leach had argued publicly in the wake of the announcement.

On Tuesday, Leach gathered with Dennis McConaghy, TransCanada's former executive vice-president of corporate development, and Martha Hall Findlay, president of the Canada West Foundation and once a Liberal MP for a Toronto riding, to hash the matter out.

Leach contended that Energy East's fate was clear once Trump was elected. Oil prices are low, production predictions have been slashed, and once Keystone XL was back on the table, the less-efficient Energy East was doomed. "It was the most expensive of the pipeline projects, so the one you naturally take off the deck," he said.

The Energy East panel, left to right: Andrew Leach, Dennis McConaghy and Martha Hall Findlay.

McConaghy took issue with that position. Energy East already had shipping contracts lined up, he said, and while Alberta might indeed maintain adequate pipeline supply if both Keystone XL and the TransMountain pipeline are approved, the fate of those two projects is still uncertain. (Keystone XL is still awaiting sign-off from Nebraska's state government, while TransMountain must face an interprovincial intransigence so entrenched that Alberta premier Rachel Notley plans to go on a cross-country road trip to support the project.) Energy East would have been a viable third option, and oil companies were willing to pay the price of potentially having too much capacity.

"The real tragedy of losing Energy East was that a set of circumstances evolved to reach a point where TransCanada couldn't just suspend the project, but went on to terminate it, and that was fundamentally driven by a conviction they could never get the permit," he said.

The regulatory process has simply become so unpredictable that no sane company will throw billions of dollars behind a project that can be cancelled on a political whim, just as Northern Gateway was, he said.

"There is total uncertainty in this country about whether we can get anything built," Hall Findlay said, adding that among resource companies Canada was beginning to acquire the reputation for political uncertainty of a banana republic.

There is no political clarity around what this country wants or what it will approve, she added. The approvals process is now taking decades, in hopes of creating a social license that will never be granted by staunch anti-oilsands activists. The cost of that delay for business can reach hundreds of millions of dollars per month.

Dennis McConaghy: I helped plan Energy East, and I know the government's excuses are bunk( http://nationalpost.com/opinion/i-helped-plan-energy-east-and-i-know-the-governments-excuses-are-bunk/wcm/975aa96e-2782-4727-8c6e-fb6ab6663eb4[http://nationalpost.com/opinion/i-helped-plan-energy-east-and-i-know-the-governments-excuses-are-bunk/wcm/975aa96e-2782-4727-8c6e-fb6ab6663eb4] )

National Post View: Surprise, surprise, the government sabotages yet another energy project( http://nationalpost.com/opinion/national-post-view-surprise-surprise-the-government-sabotages-yet-another-energy-project[http://nationalpost.com/opinion/national-post-view-surprise-surprise-the-government-sabotages-yet-another-energy-project] )

Kenneth Green: On Energy East, Trudeau and Notley faked saying 'yes' but governed by 'no'( http://nationalpost.com/opinion/on-energy-east-trudeau-and-notley-faked-saying-yes-but-governed-by-no/wcm/95324990-897c-4918-9594-4d3f4f703ebf[http://nationalpost.com/opinion/on-energy-east-trudeau-and-notley-faked-saying-yes-but-governed-by-no/wcm/95324990-897c-4918-9594-4d3f4f703ebf] )

McConaghy said that if the government wants to impose an even-handed carbon strategy, well, fine. Just make that clear upfront and apply it to all industries equally.

"It's not like these points haven't been made to the Trudeau government," he said. The government heard all these gripes and then "dismissed all the actual problems and instead advocated for more open-ended engagement, as if the regulatory process were a focus group as opposed to a technocratic exercise."

In the eyes of both Hall Findlay and McConaghy, nothing exemplified this more than Energy East. After the regulatory process had begun, the NEB said that it would take into consideration greenhouse gas emissions from the oilsands and the oil burned after it left the line rather than just the emissions of the actual pipeline. This was untenable, they argued, the sort of standard that would never be applied to central Canadian industries. It would be like judging the approval of an auto plant based on the lifetime emissions of all the cars it produced.

"The final straw was moving the goalposts," Hall Findlay said.

"Establish what the strategy is and then let our regulatory bodies implement those directions. But let them do their jobs. If every decision then comes back to what is a political win, we will not get anything done."

TransCanada executives announce the company's Energy East Pipeline project on Aug. 1, 2013.

And there was no doubt in Hall Findlay's mind that the cancellation of Energy East was celebrated in the Prime Minister's office.

"When that announcement was made, there were champagne bottles popping in Ottawa," she said. As the Liberals face more competition from the NDP, the pipeline "would have been a major, major headache for the federal Liberals."

Despite this, both Hall Findlay and Leach warned about the increasingly vicious rhetoric currently being bandied about across provincial lines: UCP leader Jason Kenney has said he would scrap Alberta's carbon tax and cut permits to oil pipelines feeding B.C. if it continues to stall the TransMountain expansion. Those threats only add to the culture of political uncertainty.

But McConaghy nonetheless echoed the darker sentiment now rippling through much of the province.

"I think it's naive to think that in a scenario where Keystone XL doesn't happen because of Nebraska and TransMountain (falters) because the federal government didn't enforce (its regulatory approval, the idea that Alberta is going to be saying 'We stepped up. We applied the most stringent carbon tax in the country and you stiffed us on market access,'" he said.

"No one should think the political reaction to that isn't going to be extreme."

. Email: jgerson@nationalpost.com( jgerson@nationalpost.com ) Twitter: jengerson( //twitter.com/jengerson )


CO 
tracan : TransCanada Corporation

IN 
i665 : Lodgings | i66 : Hotels/Restaurants | ilea : Leisure/Arts/Hospitality | i1 : Energy | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

RE 
caab : Alberta | cana : Canada | calg : Calgary | namz : North America

SE News
HD Notley plans speaking tour to build support for controversial pipeline project
BY Reid Southwick
CR Postmedia Network
WC 886 words
PD 8 November 2017
SN Mayerthorpe Freelancer
SC MYRTHR
ED Final
PG A26
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Mayerthorpe Freelancer

LP 

As Kinder Morgan's pipeline expansion in British Columbia faces a fresh challenge, Premier Rachel Notley will speak to business crowds in three provinces in an attempt to build support for the controversial project considered critical for Alberta's energy sector.

Notley said in an interview Sunday she will bring her sales pitch to Toronto, Ottawa, Calgary, Edmonton and Vancouver later this month in the hopes of convincing more Canadians the Trans Mountain expansion project is in the country's best interest.

TD 

"We are a very small economic player internationally, and we punch well above our weight, but we're not going to be able to do that if we become paralyzed by very parochial decision-making," she said.

"The oil and gas industry continues to contribute significantly to national economic growth... To walk away from it is negligent. It's economically negligent."

Kinder Morgan's project, already faced with legal challenges, has been met with new resistance in Burnaby, B.C., where the municipal government has not issued permits to allow for the $7.4-billion pipeline expansion.

Arguing Burnaby is intentionally delaying construction, the company has asked the National Energy Board to intervene and allow for work to begin. That city counters it is following its process for reviewing similar development applications and rejects the idea it is dragging its feet.

Alberta will throw its support behind Kinder Morgan before the NEB, which may review the case through written submissions or a short hearing.

While United Conservative Party Leader Jason Kenney has publicly mused about potential economic retaliation against B.C., if that province is successful in blocking or stalling Kinder Morgan's project, Notley said she's not interested in "irresponsible sabre-rattling."

"We're going to make the case in a reasonable and responsible way as long as the matter is still alive, which it is," the premier said.

Notley, who begins her tour Nov. 20 at the Empire Club of Canada in Toronto, may be preaching to the converted as she appears before pro-development business crowds across the country.

When she speaks at the Greater Vancouver Board of Trade Nov. 30, her audience will likely be sympathetic, but it will give her a platform to reach other British Columbians who can be swayed, as she attracts local media attention, said George Hoberg, a professor at the University of British Columbia.

"I suspect her goal is to reach the political middle in B.C., to make the best case to those who are not in the camp of active, adamant opponents," Hoberg said in email exchange.

"That audience is critical to how responsive the (B.C.) NDP government is likely to be to pipeline opponents. It will also be very important in the dynamics of protest and police response that will occur, should construction ramp up."

Hoberg, who teaches environmental and natural resource policy, also warned that "First Nation and environmental opponents to the pipeline will do their best to greet Notley and make sure their message continues to get attention as well."

Notley said her government - which has attempted to secure support for pipelines by imposing a climate change agenda that includes a carbon tax and cap on oilsands emissions - has "reasonable levels of credibility" among Canadians who are concerned about the environment.

"There are people who still can have their mind changed, and it's important to get the facts out there," she said.

Prasad Panda, energy critic for the United Conservative Party, supports Notley's move but argues she should have invited him and other opposition MLAs to join her in a united front.

Panda said he believes Notley genuinely backs the oil and gas industry, but he questioned her decision making, having appointed environmentalists Tzeporah Berman and Karen Mahon to an oilsands advisory panel.

They were among several panelists who were excused in June, not because of their beliefs, but because the group's focus had shifted.

Both activists have openly opposed the Trans Mountain pipeline. Mahon was recently arrested after she and three other protestors took to kayaks and roped themselves to a barge near Kinder Morgan's marine terminal in Burnaby.

"For the last two years, (Notley) was living in a fool's paradise thinking that by imposing a carbon tax and by imposing the cap on oilsands development, she would get social license, but that is not the case," Panda said.

Kinder Morgan chief executive Steve Kean recently warned that delays in securing permits and regulatory approvals could put the project nine months behind schedule, though the company is exploring measures to speed things up.

The company has also warned that every month of delay from its planned December 2019 in-service date would directly cost as much as $35 million, and another $90 million a month in lost revenue.

The B.C. government has vowed to use any means at its disposal to stop the project, which would twin Kinder Morgan's existing line, more than tripling its capacity and getting more Alberta crude to tidewater for export. It also faces legal challenges by environmentalists, Indigenous communities and B.C. municipalities.

rsouthwick@postmedia.com


ART 
Larry Wong | Postmedia Network / Alberta Premier Rachel Notley speaks at an event.;

NS 
cprdop : Facility Openings | c24 : Capacity/Facilities | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News

RE 
cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | vancv : Vancouver | namz : North America

IPD 
News | kinder,pipeline,expansion,british,columbia,faces

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document MYRTHR0020171108edb800005


SE Editorials
HD Editorial: NDP isn't consistent
BY David Marsden, Calgary Herald
WC 445 words
PD 24 October 2017
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

If Premier Rachel Notley wants to continue to dismiss opposition to pipelines by her federal and British Columbia NDP counterparts, she should lobby to make the Alberta party a distinct identity.

Unlike parties such as the Liberals, the New Democrats are integrated at the provincial and federal levels. So when Albertans sign up to support Notley and her colleagues, they automatically become members of the federal NDP. That's why it's strange to hear Notley say federal NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh's hostility toward pipelines is of no consequence.

TD 

"I'm not going to get too wrapped up in what people who are not in government are doing in other parts of the country, in hypothetical conversations, over which they have no agency," Notley said last week.

Certainly, it's true that as the leader of the third largest party in Parliament, Singh isn't in a position to give a green light or red light to energy projects, but the optics are terrible. Notley's federal leader is going around the country whipping up opposition to projects her government says are not only in Alberta's interest, but in the national interest.

More jarringly, her British Columbia NDP cousin, Premier John Horgan, has pledged to use every tool at his disposal to block the Kinder Morgan pipeline expansion, which was approved by the federal government and his predecessor, Christy Clark.

It's not uncommon to have disagreements within families, but surely Notley must realize it's untenable to have her colleagues working against her in such bold fashion.

Singh was in Vancouver on Friday, where he said he has three criteria that must be met for any energy projects to be approved - that Indigenous rights are respected, that Canada can meet its climate change goals if the pipeline goes ahead, and that the projects prioritize local jobs. Neither Trans Mountain nor the now-shelved Energy East projects met those criteria, said Singh.

Still, the federal leader praised Notley for her government's initiatives directed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

"It needs to be pointed out, Premier Notley has the most aggressive and comprehensive climate change policy in Canada. We won't achieve our climate goals if we don't have a premier like Rachel Notley in Alberta," said Singh.

Ah, that would be the same climate change plan that was supposed to earn so-called social license for pipelines - support that hasn't been forthcoming from Singh and Horgan and their sort.

If Alberta's NDP party has different views than its federal counterpart, it should take steps to separate the two organizations.


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
caab : Alberta | cabc : British Columbia | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
premier,rachel,notley,continue,dismiss,opposition

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020171024edao002mh


SE Comment
HD Pipeline cancellation national humiliation
CR Postmedia Network
WC 394 words
PD 19 October 2017
SN Strathroy Age Dispatch
SC STRATHRY
ED Final
PG A4
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Strathroy Age Dispatch

LP 

The scrapping of TransCanada Corp's $15.7-billion Energy East pipeline is regrettable.

The fact the decision was prompted by uncertainty about the regulatory review the project faced is deplorable.

TD 

The National Energy Board - responding to signals from the government of Justin Trudeau - insisted that upstream and downstream greenhouse gas emissions form part of the review, a requirement it added midway through the process. That means the national regulator would have considered the amount of emissions generated by the extraction of the oil, as well as when it was burned, perhaps as fuel to power Quebecmade Bombardier jets.

The NEB's overreaching test was too much. It seems strange the government and its various arms'-length bodies don't fret about the emissions produced by Bombardier's various products, which are dependent on the very resource Energy East was going to transport from Alberta to Quebec and the East Coast.

Federal Infrastructure Minister Amarjeet Sohi said the move by TransCanada was a business decision and he dismissed suggestions the culprit was the NEB's new rules.

"It's the company's decision not to proceed with Energy East based on their business analysis. It has nothing to do with the federal government's review process," Sohi said. Evidently that wasn't the case. "There remains substantial uncertainty around the scope, timing and cost associated with the regulatory review of the projects," the company said of the pipeline and a proposed marine terminal in New Brunswick.

"After completing its careful review of these factors, the existing and likely future delays resulting from the regulatory process, the associated cost implications and the increasingly challenging issues and obstacles facing the projects, the applicants will not be proceeding further with the projects."

It is not only an embarrassment that the pipeline's cancellation ensures the East's continued dependence on foreign oil, but it is a scandal that Canada can't get such projects built in a timely fashion.

Even pipelines that have been approved are met with opposition and legal challenges, raising doubts about the so-called social license the NDP imagined its provincial carbon tax would earn.

The list of abandoned energy proposals now tops $56 billion in the past year alone. The Trudeau government needs to recognize the importance of such pursuits to the country's economy.


CO 
tracan : TransCanada Corporation | bbdr : Bombardier Inc

IN 
i1 : Energy | i364 : Aerospace Products/Parts | iaer : Aerospace/Defense | iindstrls : Industrial Goods | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

NS 
c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

IPD 
Opinion | scrapping,transcanada,energy,pipeline,regrettable,decision

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document STRATHRY20171019edaj00006


SE Columnists
HD Nelson: Time and season for Notley to change course
BY Chris Nelson, For The Calgary Herald
WC 716 words
PD 16 October 2017
SN Postmedia Breaking News
SC CWNS
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Postmedia Breaking News

LP 

Ecclesiastes 3 is unlikely to be required reading among the political strategists and general hangers-about charged with plotting a repeat victory for our current provincial government.

It's a pity, as they might learn something, because indeed for every thing there is a season, and a time for every purpose under heaven.

TD 

And right now, it's becoming glaringly obvious the ongoing, two-year-long strategy of borrowing a fortune while hoping Alberta's economy does one of those bust-to-boom routines is wearing thin.

Back in the springtime, there was a little jaunt in the step of the treasurer when he spoke of green shoots, followed by a glint in the premier's eye as she waxed lyrical about turning some corner.

Well, six months on and halfway through this dismal financial year, that jaunt is morphing into a limp and the corner looks as though it leads to Dead End Street. Nope, things are not rebounding the way the government undoubtedly expected.

Just like our current backyards, those green shoots are gone and a season of reckoning is upon us. Thoughts of sure-fire, rapid growth are now only for the foolish or criminally optimistic.

Which, in political terms, means this government's strategy is hitting a brick wall comprised of stubbornly high unemployment and dangerously worrisome levels of borrowing. Halfway through their mandate and Notley's crew are running out of time, because if things don't change soon, they are done like the proverbial dinner.

This month is already proving a nightmare. First came news TransCanada Corp. is pulling out of the Energy East pipeline project after facing so much criticism, political grandstanding and shifting regulatory sands they probably breathed a huge sigh of relief despite the disappointment.

There was no relief in Edmonton, however. This was a body blow to the government's much-ballyhooed social license strategy, in which we all get whacked with a carbon tax with the explicit promise this would make the rest of Canada all warm and cuddly toward Alberta pipelines.

Nope, that longed-for love-in didn't get too far. So now all eyes, and a heck of a lot of votes, are tied to measurable progress of the westward-ho pipeline project, otherwise known as the Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain expansion, a project that the government across whose territory it must proceed is intent on delaying and ultimately ditching. Yes, our prime minister is on board, but remind me again how many federal seats the Grits hold here in Alberta?

As if that wasn't bad enough, we had the latest woes our monthly labour statistics provide.

The good news is unemployment fell to 7.9 per cent, but delve just slightly below the surface and that appears like that old joke about the man who's just lost a leg getting a decent offer on his slippers. The reason it went down is the labour force fell - at this rate, we'll have nobody out of a job because everyone's quit looking.

The number of people working in September actually fell by 7,800. Now perish the thought the looming minimum wage hike could have had anything to do with that - but the fact is the biggest drop came in accommodation and food service employment, where many such low-paid jobs reside.

No doubt the close to 8,000 jobs in that sector that vanished in the month prior to the mandated pay hike would just be statistical noise to Labour Minister Christina Gray. In her cosy world, the metadata is already counted and there'll be no turning back.

That's symptomatic of the bigger problem. Other than hoping oil prices suddenly ratchet skyward, there's no other plan to reduce our enormous borrowing binge, as any suggestion of trimming spending is greeted with shrieks of brutality and heartlessness.

Except time is running out and hope isn't a strategy. So now, in the second half of her mandate, Premier Rachel Notley needs to rethink this government's policies, because, as in Ecclesiastes 3, there is a time to keep and a time to cast away.

Chris Nelson is a Calgary writer.


NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
caab : Alberta | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
ecclesiastes,unlikely,required,reading,political,strategists

PUB 
Canwest News Service

AN 
Document CWNS000020171016edag002jp


SE Opinion
HD Pipeline cancellation national humiliation
CR Orillia Packet & Times
WC 399 words
PD 13 October 2017
SN The Packet & Times
SC ORLAPT
ED Final
PG A4
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 The Packet & Times

LP 

The scrapping of Trans Canada Corp's $15.7-billion Energy East pipeline is regrettable. The fact the decision was prompted by uncertainty about the regulatory review the project faced is deplorable.

The National Energy Board - responding to signals from the government of Justin Trudeau - insisted that upstream and downstream greenhouse gas emissions form part of the review, a requirement it added midway through the process. That means the national regulator would have considered the amount of emissions generated by the extraction of the oil, as well as when it was burned, perhaps as fuel to power Quebec-made Bombardier jets.

TD 

The NEB's overreaching test was too much. It seems strange the government and its various arms'-length bodies don't fret about the emissions produced by Bombardier's various products, which are dependent on the very resource Energy East was going to transport from Alberta to Quebec and the East Coast.

Federal Infrastructure Minister Amarjeet Sohi said the move by TransCanada was a business decision and he dismissed suggestions the culprit was the NEB's new rules.

"It's the company's decision not to proceed with Energy East based on their business analysis. It has nothing to do with the federal government's review process," Sohi said.

Evidently that wasn't the case. "There remains substantial uncertainty around the scope, timing and cost associated with the regulatory review of the projects," the company said of the pipeline and a proposed marine terminal in New Brunswick.

"After completing its careful review of these factors, the existing and likely future delays resulting from the regulatory process, the associated cost implications and the increasingly challenging issues and obstacles facing the projects, the applicants will not be proceeding further with the projects."

It is not only an embarrassment that the pipeline's cancellation ensures the East's continued dependence on foreign oil, but it is a scandal that Canada can't get such projects built in a timely fashion.

Even pipelines that have been approved are met with opposition and legal challenges, raising doubts about the so-called social license the NDP imagined its provincial carbon tax would earn.

The list of abandoned energy proposals now tops $56 billion in the past year alone. The Trudeau government needs to recognize the importance of such pursuits to the country's economy. - Postmedia Network

SE News
HD 'An attack on Alberta'; Alberta politicians react with anger, disappointment to Energy East's cancellation
BY Vincent Mcdermott
CR With files from Emma Graney
WC 495 words
PD 10 October 2017
SN Fort McMurray Today
SC FTMTDY
ED Final
PG A2
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Fort McMurray Today

LP 

TransCanada's decision to cancel its Energy East pipeline was met with outrage from Alberta's politicians, with everything from the economy to policies passed by the prime minister and premier blamed for its fate.

In a statement, Fort McMurray-Conklin MLA Brian Jean called the cancellation "an attack on Alberta," while other provinces have "declared war on Alberta" over pipelines.

TD 

"They are cheering for Canada to fail and threatening national unity," he said. "The political blockading of Canada's energy products is not acceptable and must be fought every step of the way."

Jean also blamed the Alberta NDP's carbon tax as a major factor influencing TransCanada's decision, arguing their belief that "social license" would lead to pipeline approvals was doomed to failure.

"Canada will now continue to import foreign dictator oil into our refineries instead of Alberta oil," he said.

Premier Rachel Notley said TransCanada's decision was "an unfortunate outcome for Canadians."

In a statement, the premier did not address the criticisms from Jean and her other opponents, instead blaming "a broad range of factors." She then challenged the National Energy Board "to send a clear message on what the future of project reviews look like in Canada.

"We believe this nationbuilding project would have benefited all of Canada through new jobs, investment, energy security and the ability to displace oil being imported into Canada from overseas and the United States," she said. "Investors need confidence and we look forward to seeing that certainty in place soon."

The Energy East project would have connected the oilsands from a TransCanada hub in Hardisty, Alta. to refineries in Saint John, N.B. The company suspended its application last month for 30 days before making its decision last week.

TransCanada had previously warned the $15.7-billion project could be cancelled.

In Ottawa, federal Infrastructure Minister Amarjeet Sohi denied changes to the NEB's new rules assessing downstream emissions harmed the project and argued TransCanada was influenced by the economy.

"It's the company's decision not to proceed with Energy East based on their business analysis. It has nothing to do with the federal government's review process," he said Thursday.

Responding to the Liberals insistence they were not responsible for the demise of Energy East, Fort McMurray-Cold Lake MP David Yurdiga said in a statement "the Liberals are the reason this is happening."

"Instead of championing ethical Alberta oil, Prime Minister Trudeau has tried to phase out the oilsands," he said. "When Canadians reject the Liberal Party, and the Conservatives form Government once again I hope TransCanada will reconsider."


ART 
Frederic Hore, Postmedia Network / Melissa Lachance of Montreal looks at a map of the proposed Energy East pipeline at a rally organized by Greenpeace and other groups at Jack Layton Park, in Hudson, Que. on July 4, 2015.;

CO 
tracan : TransCanada Corporation

IN 
i1 : Energy | imidstr : Oil/Natural Gas Midstream Operations

NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
caab : Alberta | cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
News | decision,cancel,energy,pipeline,outrage,politicians

Postmedia Network Inc.

Document FTMTDY0020171010edaa00005


HD View from the Hill
WC 1751 words
PD 5 October 2017
SN Power Play With Don Martin
SC ONHILL
LA English
CY Copyright 2017 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): DON MARTIN

DON MARTIN: Welcome back. Our Thursday MP combo of diverse political opinion joins us to talk pipelines, plaques, and a phoenix which refuses to rise. Ruby Sahota is a Liberal MP from Brampton, Michelle Rempel a Conservative MP from Calgary, and the pride of Essex, NDP MP Tracey Ramsey. Welcome to you all. Michelle, you heard Jim Carr. Tell me what's the view of Calgary on this. What's your reaction, Energy East I'm talking about?

TD 

MICHELLE REMPEL (Conservative – Alberta): You know, if the Liberals wanted to completely shut down the energy sector, I wish we would have just had that policy discussion, or the courage to have that policy discussion in parliament. The reality is between the carbon tax, which is not going to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, between even the small business tax issue this week, the changing of the rules for major energy projects which require a large capital investment, certainly the downstream emission review on this, like, come on, we're not reviewing Saudi oil for that. The tanker moratorium that, they actually shut down debate on the tanker moratorium bill after only two opposition speakers this week. I could go on and on. The reality is all of these things combined is an ideological opposition to the energy sector. You heard Jim Carr talk about the pipelines that they approved. Well, we approved four pipelines under our government. So that's fact. The other component is that the government, they refuse to stand up and acknowledge that many First Nations communities actually want some of these pipelines to be produced. We already have one of the world's strongest regulatory systems in the world, and I wish that they would have just had the courage to call it national energy program the second, but they were smart enough not to. The unfortunate thing is I think that this is going to stoke western alienation. I think that this is going to hurt the entire economy writ large, and their talking points are very, very weak and they're not cognizant of the reality that the energy sector plays in the Canadian economy.

MARTIN: Okay. It is an engine of growth out there. Tracey, where is the NDP coming down on Energy East? Is this a business decision or political obstruction? TRACEY RAMSEY (NDP – Ontario): Well this isn't a surprise because the system is broken that we're using. The process that we're using is broken. We've been saying that for a very long time. You have to include social license. You have to include the communities that are impacted. And here we saw the municipalities saying that they didn't want this, having the province weigh in. Like when you have people in a community who are objecting to what you're doing, then you have to take a serious look at that. Until they fix this process, don, you know, no project really is going to go through in the way that it should. It's not going to have every single aspect looked at, and know that that project is good for Canada. We're happy to see this happen. Obviously this is something that we were calling for. But it's not a surprise, and it's just another example of how the government needs to listen to the people in the communities that are impacted.

MARTIN: So, Ruby, I'm sure you want to weigh in somewhere between those two polar opposites.

RUBY SAHOTA (Liberal – Ontario): Absolutely. Government has been listening, and therefore that's why we have a process that has been working and takes into account what Indigenous people are saying. It takes into account the issue with the emissions. And we have successfully, under this exact same process, the process has not changed regardless of what the Conservatives want to sell to people, the process is the same and we've approved three pipelines since that time. Two oil pipelines, TransCanada, Line 3, a gas pipeline, Nova Gas, and that's created over 25,000 jobs. How many jobs did the Conservatives create in that area? Zero! Because you did not, the fact is you did not...

REMPEL: Whoa, whoa, Ruby, come to Calgary.

SAHOTA: ...any oil pipelines in ten years. We've approved three.

REMPEL: Keystone, Anchor Loop, the Line Nine reversal. Wrong, wrong, wrong, and the reality is that there's over 200,000 people that are out of work in Alberta. So anybody in Alberta that's talking about jobs created under the Trudeau government are actually going to be throwing tomatoes at their screen right now. That is such complete malarkey. And I just wish, again, I mean we're going to continue to stand up for the energy sector, but I think what everybody is going to be doing today is looking at the Trudeau government and saying, look, why didn't you just have the courage to stand up and say we don't want this to happen. Why just try and trick Canadians into thinking anything otherwise?

SAHOTA: We absolutely wanted it to happen. It was a business decision at the end of the day made by TransCanada.

REMPEL: But why isn't Canada open for business on this? If it's a business... SAHOTA: We're absolutely open to business.

REMPEL: No, what you've done is you've, you have changed the rules on a billion dollar capital decision. You have changed the rules on the taxation.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

REMPEL: You have changed rules and the context and labour.

MARTIN: Go ahead Tracey.

RAMSEY: This is an example of how broken the process was under the previous Conservative government. It continues to be under the Liberals. And until this process gets fixed, it has to get fixed. This is broken. We saw the social licence today coming to play, communities coming into play.

REMPEL: What exactly is broken about this?

RAMSEY: Listening to communities. You have to take into account the communities that this is traveling through, not just where it's coming and where it's going through.

MARTIN: I got to move on. We're running out of time and I want to get to this issue because the "New York Times", the "Washington Post", the "Times of Israel", the "BBC" are all covering the story of the missing mention on our brand new national holocaust memorial down there. There's no mention of the Jewish population that was exterminated in the gas chambers. All we've got in place is that millions of men, women, and children were murdered during the holocaust, and the survivors who persevered were able to make their way to Canada after one of the darkest chapters in history. The plaque didn't mention anything about Jews. It has since been removed. The government, like what's your reaction to this?

RAMSEY: This is a very serious oversight. You know this, we're glad that it's down, but this is a very serious oversight that's hurtful to people who are in Canada who are descendants of people who are Jewish who faced anti-Semitism. There needs to be an acknowledgment of what exactly happened there, and it can't be this kind of just vague reference to the amount of people that were murdered in the holocaust, so it needs to be fixed. It's just a very unfortunate and really a big mistake by the Liberals not catching that this should have been an important piece.

MARTIN: How can you not proofread a plaque, or did they just decide they couldn't single out one set of victims and decide just to lump it in as men, women and children. What did you think when you heard this?

REMPEL: I guess two points. First to that, you know, if you go to any holocaust memorial around the world, be it Yad Vashem, or the American holocaust memorial, the communities that built those take great pains to talk about the Roma, or Jehovah's Witnesses, or members of the LGBTQ community that were also included, but the reality is I think a key component of anti-Semitism to this day is people who purport that the Jewish community somehow made the holocaust up. And the main way that we can fight anti-Semitism is by strongly pushing back, and saying unless we recognize how many members of the Jewish community were killed simply because of their faith under extreme conditions, the saying never again won't actually happen. So, you know, this is a pretty big oversight, and one that I'm glad was corrected. But I mean, yes, proofreading a plaque should have happened.

MARTIN: And a bit of a global, I mean laughing stock is the wrong word, but certainly we're being held up to ridicule around the globe for this. I mean surely someone, who should be held responsible for this, Ruby?

SAHOTA: I don't disagree with anything my colleagues have said. It is a time in our history that needs to be acknowledged, and we need to learn from it. We need to call it what it was, and, you know, over six million Jews died, so there was no excuse. We really appreciate that (inaudible) flagged the issue right away and immediately it was removed. On the monument overall, there are over 50 mentions of the Jewish people, but this plaque in particular had that oversight, and I don't know how that happened but I'm really grateful that it was flagged and removed and it's going to be corrected, rightfully so.

MARTIN: I know. Well we were supposed to talk phoenix, but I'm out of time. And I think phoenix is going to continue to flounder around for a while.

REMPEL: We just want people to get paid, like me.

MARTIN: Are you having trouble getting paid?

REMPEL: MPs aren't supposed to get paid, Don, but, no, I think it's, you know, across party lines, this is really affecting a lot of public servants and they need to, it needs to be fixed. MARTIN: Okay. Well we'll save the blame game for another time. All right, thank you all. Have a great break week and a happy Thanksgiving. Coming up, fighting back against the military's silent killer. Please stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)


NS

RE 
cana : Canada | calg : Calgary | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

Bell Media Inc.

AN

SE METRO NEWS | NEWS | CANADA
HD Risks from deadly H2S gas in Prairies were kept from public: Investigation
BY Robert Cribb, Torstar News Services/ Patti Sonntag, Michener Awards Foundation/ P.W. Elliott, Universty of Regina / Elizabeth McSheffrey, National Observer
WC 4195 words
PD 2 October 2017
SN Metro Canada
SC MOTTA
PG 0
LA English
CY Copyright 2017. Free Daily News Group Inc. Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction or distribution is prohibited without permission. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

OXBOW, SASK.-The two-storey cedar home where Shirley Galloway lives with her family was a solitary dot on the Saskatchewan prairie when they moved here 21 years ago.

The view from the front porch, once a landscape of rolling hills, horse pastures and lush river valley, has been transformed.

TD 

Today, Oxbow is surrounded by bobbing, black steel pump jacks and flare stacks burning off hydrogen sulphide and other dangerous gases that rise with the oil and trail off in ribbons of flame over green fields.

Late in the afternoon of Oct. 30, 2012, Galloway, a 53-year-old registered nurse, heard screams from the front yard.

Galloway dashed out to find a teenage family member vomiting and the air thick with the rotten-egg smell of sour gas - hydrogen sulphide (H2S).

Galloway, who trains oil workers to survive these same events, knew what to do.

She pulled the teen inside, grabbed an air monitor and held it out the door. The reading was off the dial - more than 100 parts per million - a level immediately dangerous to human health.

Saskatchewan's oil boom has brought jobs for many. For others, it has brought fear, injury and one death.

The number of "fracked" wells in the Bakken shale oilfield alone increased from 75 in 2004 to nearly 3,000 in 2013, according to a 2016 paper by the Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives. The promise of prosperity, similar to its southern neighbour North Dakota's Bakken boom, has been embraced by a province struggling to diversify its economy.

A national investigation[https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2017/10/01/that-rotten-stench-in-the-air-its-the-smell-of-deadly-gas-and-secrecy.html] by the Toronto Star, the National Observer, Global News and journalism schools at Regina, Concordia, Ryerson and UBC has uncovered failures by industry and government to respond to - and warn the public about - the serious and sometimes deadly threat of H2S gas wafting across Saskatchewan.

Documents obtained through freedom-of-information requests and from whistleblowers - internal correspondence, meeting minutes, presentations and inspection reports - disclose findings of failures in performance by oil and gas companies, including serious infractions, failed safety audits, daily H2S readings beyond provincial air quality standards and a death in 2014.

Yet regulatory standards remain largely unchanged and H2S incidents and risks remain hidden from the public.

The teen overcome in Galloway's yard eventually recovered but missed school for several days with nausea and headaches.

H2S can be an insidious killer.

Heavier than air, it tends to settle in ravines and valleys.

Just above the level Galloway's monitor detected - 100 parts per million - H2S causes olfactory paralysis, leaving a victim unable to detect the rotten-egg smell. Continued exposure at that level may cause death within 48 hours.

A person exposed to a highly concentrated plume of the gas - at 1,000 parts per million - may die rapidly from respiratory paralysis, or over the course of days, from an inflammatory reaction in the lungs.

Victims effectively suffocate.

The government issued no public warning after Galloway reported the plume at her home because "there was no evidence that this was a widespread failure." But inside government and industry offices, documents indicate the seriousness of H2S issues that led to years of meetings, audits and proposed regulatory reforms.

On April 7, 2014, government and industry officials deliberated about releasing data that showed H2S "hotspots" across southeastern Saskatchewan.

"Government may be accused of hiding information," the notes read. "Public will want to know: 1. What are the areas? 2. How is it managed? 3. How is the government making sure it's managed?" one unnamed official told the meeting. "Are we creating a risk by not releasing this data immediately?"

Despite acknowledging "significant" public health risks from H2S, at least some officials present expressed concern about "sensitivity in this data (because) there are residents living in these areas."

No release followed.

Three weeks later, government-proposed fines for emission breaches - up to $1 million in penalties - were rejected by two major industry groups. In a letter to the ministry dated April 29, 2014, the Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP) and Explorers and Producers Association of Canada (EPAC) called the proposed penalties "unsuitable."

A former ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of losing his current job in the industry, says "almost every amendment was being rejected."

EPAC officials declined comment.

Terry Abel, CAPP's spokesperson, said the letter was intended to explain that, "in some cases, fines aren't appropriate at all ... If there's an unsafe operation, it should be shut down. It shouldn't be operating. That's the best way to ensure the public safety is protected."

The proposed fines were dropped.

The next month, Michael Bunz, a 38-year-old salesman supplying chemicals to oil and gas facilities, lay in a shack 80 kilometres from the Galloway house, dead after being exposed to H2S.

The official incident report filed with the Ministry of the Economy, which regulates Saskatchewan's oilfields, makes no mention of Bunz's death.

These regulators "are really thinking about the economic health of the province," says Emily Eaton, a professor at the University of Regina who has studied the relationship between the oil industry and the government. Eaton is a member of the Corporate Mapping Project.

A shift in 2012 - from the Ministry of Energy and Resources to a new Ministry of the Economy tasked with regulating natural resource extraction and promoting economic development - changed the ministry's role from watchdog to partner, she says.

"They're thinking about returns on investment ... The industry should really be regulated by those that have the interests of the environment first."

Ministry field staff raised this concern at a meeting on July 1, 2015, between government and industry.

"The role of the regulator needs to be adjusted," the meeting's minutes read. "The regulators are acting as consultants in some situations. The role of the regulator is to enforce the rules and if the rules are clear and if enforcement is consistent and clear then, 'cultural' changes can be made."

In its statement, the ministry rejects criticisms of conflict of interest or lax enforcement.

"Within the Ministry of the Economy, the petroleum and natural gas division carries out industry regulation," wrote the department's spokeswoman, Deb Young. "It is not involved in investment attraction, royalty and tax assessment and land sales. It is solely focused on well, facility and pipeline regulation."

That regulation has not included fines or prosecutions.

The ministry has not issued a single fine against any industry company "for well over a decade," Doug MacKnight, assistant deputy minister responsible for petroleum and natural gas, said in an interview.

"Generally, we don't have to resort to that," he said. "It's usually just a notice to the operator to bring themselves into compliance."

Prosecutions have also not been part of the ministry's enforcement practices because non-compliance was dealt with "through other enforcement actions," reads the ministry's statement.

Other enforcement actions include increased inspections and staff, high-tech equipment for detecting emissions and a $69-million inspection reporting database (which can't be accessed by the public).

Still, complaints of illness from residents and workers continue.

"I will sometimes get faint, like I will fall over and I have to find a seat quickly," says Lori Erhardt, a United Church minister and musician living near Oxbow who believes her chronic illness is related to emissions.

"I have had a variety of diagnoses, most of them end with "i-t-i-s," which means inflammation ... If something gets inflamed, if it's blood vesicles, you feel it through your body."

Among the five years' worth of documents obtained by this investigation is an April 2012 PowerPoint presentation to CAPP members by the director of the province's petroleum and natural gas division. It includes a map of southeastern Saskatchewan showing a bloom of red and orange circles, labelled "critical sour gas locations."

Sources say ministry staff pushed to make the data public but senior government officials said "there's no goddamn way that is going to be released," according to the former ministry source.

"There's an institutional reluctance to make this information public," he said. "The public should be able to see all the information that legislators have identified as public information such as sour gas and inspection reports."

The ministry statement says the map was never approved for release because some data was out of date, not comprehensive and "could provide the public and industry with a false understanding of risk associated with a particular well or facility."

After the Galloway incident, the ministry inspected 11 oil and gas facilities. All failed "with serious infractions," including releasing H2S at lethal levels "that may be exceeding 150,000 (parts per million)," Brad Herald, CAPP's Saskatchewan operations manager, wrote to the board of governors in December 2012.

Those levels are 150 times the amount that could cause instant death.

Among the causes: "It is believed that inadequate training on the installation and operation of equipment is ... contributing to the air quality issues."

CAPP's Abel said in an interview the "unsafe" facilities responsible for those breaches should not have been operating.

"They should have been shut down," he said. "When you follow the rules, processing and production of sour gas is absolutely safe. If you don't follow the rules, it can pose a health risk. So ultimately, those operators at those facilities were responsible."

Neither CAPP nor its industry partners made the health risks public. And no ministry fines or prosecutions followed.

Internally, CAPP quickly mobilized to develop a public relations and damage control plan:

"There are growing public concerns regarding the air quality issues in southeast Saskatchewan," Herald wrote, noting a petition and a Facebook page.

"The Ministry fields one to two public complaints concerning odours per week and the issue is garnering increasing political attention . . . This has the potential to become a broader industry reputation/social license concern and warrants immediate attention by operators in the region . . . Communications is preparing key messages in the event that there is media profile."

CAPP received a warning the next month after consulting a scientist with expertise on managing toxic substances, internal emails show. The scientist expressed disappointment noting that H2S failures were "so easy to avoid."

The scientist urged the industry lobby group to develop and implement a new code of practice to control dangerous emissions and get ahead of the problem by publicly denouncing unacceptable practices. The scientist also recommended that the industry group pressure the province to step up inspections.

The ministry, in meetings with industry, proposed similar reforms.

In a letter sent in March 2013 then-energy minister Tim McMillan - now president and CEO of CAPP - warned companies to meet "compliance obligations" or face "escalated enforcement, penalty and/or prosecution."

Ministry and industry met four times between 2012 and 2014 to plot strategy, including emergency planning zones, a public communications document, a code of practice and a licensing regime for high-risk, single-well batteries.

Those plans were never adopted, a ministry statement confirms.

"Instead, the Ministry chose to take a risk-based approach to managing the sour gas issue that included increased field inspections and improved data collection." Eighteen wells that had been venting sour gas were ordered to be "shut-in" in 2012/2013.

From 2013 to the summer of 2014, the ministry began implementing "an aggressive inspection and enforcement schedule to reduce sour gas emission" that included suspension orders against 30 facilities owing to "H2S management issues," the statement reads.

During that effort, H2S would claim its most high-profile victim in Saskatchewan.

Michael Bunz, a salesman for Nalco Champion, died on May 22, 2014, while taking samples in a shed located in a provincial park between Carlyle and Kipling. A valve on the tank broke and oil, water and H2S spewed into his face.

An incident report submitted by the tank's owner, Harvest Operations Corp., states simply: "Spill occurred as a result of a failed valve."

Nowhere does it mention Bunz's death.

Instead, his death is marked by a gravestone in a small cemetery near Wawota, where the father of two young daughters lived a few doors away from his parents, Dianne and Allan.

The black, polished stone, with an image of Bunz wearing his Saskatchewan Roughriders jersey and hat, calls him "Bunzy" and reads: "In loving memory of Emma and Olivia's Daddy."

"He didn't really talk about those dangers," Dianne says. "We knew what it's like to work in the oil industry. My husband did for 20 years. We knew about H2S but I wasn't aware that he was going on site and doing the testing."

The summer before he died, Allan drove his son to the Nalco office to quit. Michael's brother-in-law, who had worked there, had left and "things had been pretty tough," Michael said, marked by long days and heavy workload.

"He was going to hand his company truck in, and his boss was there ... he talked (Michael) out of it," Allan says. "This company wanted him because he never ever phoned in sick or anything. He'd just go to work. And they offered him more money, so he stayed."

Nalco Champion is facing three charges under the province's occupational health and safety legislation for failing to provide Bunz with a respirator and to ensure he entered a dangerous situation with a second worker. A conviction would result in a fine.

The family says they were told by Nalco that the concentration of H2S in the fluids was estimated at 40,000 parts per million, more than enough to bring near-instant death.

The company sent reporters a written statement, declining further comment.

"We remain deeply saddened by the loss of our colleague, Michael Bunz. The safety of our associates, customers and communities is vitally important, and we remain committed to our robust safety policies, protocols and training programs, which include those related to hydrogen sulfide," it reads.

Allan, who spent most of his working life in the oil industry, says he learned more about H2S protection when he worked on a pig farm.

"Every person had to wear an H2S monitor. And I'm talking about the pig industry," he says. "To me, they were protecting us ... more at this simple small hog operation in Saskatchewan than the oil industry ever did the entire time I was working out there."

The couple reviewed the records documenting years of discussions between government and industry about public health risks and failed audits that were never made public. The couple called it "devastating."

"I go to work every day and I drive down the highway and I talk to my son sitting beside me," says Allan. "I say to him "tough day there, son" and I tell him how I feel . . . I feel him sitting there beside me."

How often H2S incidents happen or happened in Saskatchewan remains a mystery.

Officially, ministry officials count one death and five "documented incidents where a member of the public was exposed to unsafe levels of sour gas near a well or facility site."

None of them triggered a public statement by the government.

"There was no need for public notification since the incident was quickly dealt with at the site," reads the ministry statement.

But after dozens of interviews it is clear that H2S incidents involving residents are more common but go unreported or are not recorded properly. This is also true for workers in the oilfield.

Only months after Bunz died, Trina Hansen, an oilfield worker and part-time voice actress, was clearing a pipeline near Carlyle, Sask.

"I could have died," she says. "It's almost like you could feel like a heavy air hit your face. It's a really weird feeling. Your first reaction is to inhale. When it hits your face, you breathe it in. It's the weirdest thing. You don't think to hold your breath. It happens so fast. I stumbled backwards. I was so shocked."

Disoriented, Hansen got back in her truck and drove a couple of kilometres until she noticed she was losing her peripheral vision.

"There were white sparkles, iridescent, swirly, super-shiny and bright. I jumped out and started feeling nauseous and couldn't breathe very well. I was trying to catch my breath and dry heaving. My head started pounding."

Hansen, suffering debilitating headaches, nausea and sickness, lost her voice for two weeks.

"This happened three years ago and I still have a hard time catching my breath if I talk too fast. I'm very short of breath. I've never in my life felt like that. It was horrible."

Her voice has changed for good - it is far deeper and lower than before.

"I do a cartoon on APTN network and they said my voice totally changed. It changed two octaves pretty much. It used to be high and now it cuts out."

Hansen never reported the incident, fearing she would lose her job.

"Nobody wants to say anything. We know it's bad and dangerous. But no one wants to raise a fuss. And being a woman and trying to prove yourself out there, I never claimed WCB (Workers Compensation Board). The economy went down and I have to pay off debt with my trucking money."

Four months after Bunz's death, a secret ministry report listed 161 facilities "that may be in violation of (the ministry's) sour gas emission control."

The catch: "time and resources required to investigate and verify violations would take all available field officers over a year."

In 2014, inspections of 60 suspicious wells in 2014 turned up 36 - more than half - that were leaking so badly they had to be shut down.

Another audit found 11 out of 12 facilities failed inspection "due to H2S venting" and found 29 locations that are too close to facilities with high levels of H2S concentrations. Of the 1,352 active sour gas facilities, only 421 - 31 per cent - had "proper emission control systems."

"Almost every site had improper gas measurement," the report reads. "Discovered major contamination at two facilities as a result of spill which were not reported" to the ministry.

The ministry believes that the H2S issue is under control, saying air quality standards are being met and that inspections confirm that companies' sour gas management practices have improved. Today 27 full-time inspectors are responsible for the province's 126,000 wells and its estimated 118,000 kilometres of pipelines and flowlines, operating with a budget of $3.9 million.

In 2016-17, ministry staff inspected 18,340 wells, facilities and pipelines.

Last month, a team of researchers from Harvard and Northeastern Universities collected data in collaboration with this investigation using the same instruments employed by ministry inspectors to detect emissions invisible to the naked eye.

"In my experience measuring oil and gas activities in Texas, what struck me was that about a third of the sites we looked at had what we believed to be fugitive emissions and the high density of pump jacks," says Lourdes Vera, a doctoral student in environmental sociology at Northeastern University.

Drew Michanowicz, a post-doctoral researcher at Harvard University's School of Public Health who led the survey in Saskatchewan, said about one in five of the facilities they visited showed black smoke rising from the flaring stacks of production facilities.

"If there is black smoke, there is particulate matter that if inhaled is certainly associated with human health effects," he said. "If sources of these air pollutants are constantly impacting individuals where they live, work and play, there is the worry that they are experiencing health effects."

In interviews with landowners and records in the government database, this investigation has found recent H2S accidents, including three people who say they were sickened by H2S clouds near their homes in the past year. One said they required hospitalization after a near-fatal incident.

In January, more than four years after the H2S incident in Galloway's front yard, she and her husband were driving home when they encountered a plume of what she believes was H2S gas.

She fell ill and stayed home for three days.

"I've had arrhythmias, really wicked headaches ... I've had bouts of nausea. I wake up at night and have heart palpitations."

Galloway wrote to public officials demanding a response.

There were no consequences or fines as a result. And no official report of an incident anywhere near the Galloway property that day was filed.

That, says Galloway, is just the way it works in Saskatchewan.

"As a person living in the middle of the oilfield, you have no protection. The government doesn't care. Your MLA doesn't care. The oil companies don't care."

Unprecedented Collaboration Behind the Project

During the past nine months, an unprecedented collaboration of more than 50 journalists and editors from three Canadian media outlets, four journalism schools and a think tank have worked to chronicle the hidden price of oil in Canada.

Collectively, reporters examined thousands of industry and government documents, analyzed terabytes of data and delved into dozens of freedom-of-information requests.

"The project started with the people," says Patti Sonntag, a managing editor in the New York Times' news services division, who launched the project with a grant from the Michener Awards Foundation. Following a tip from a colleague at the Corporate Mapping Project, she did some research and reporting in Saskatchewan last fall.

Working with the previous year's Michener winner, Toronto Star journalist Robert Cribb, Sonntag created a team of students at the Ryerson, Concordia and UBC journalism schools. Concordia University's Department of Journalism volunteered to act as host and headquarters for the project.

University of Regina students reported on the ground locally, shot video and developed sources, while students at the other universities aggregated and analyzed data and interviewed experts.

"We're pulling these four different schools from across the country and looking at it from all different aspects," says Janelle Blakley, a University of Regina student reporter whose team mapped spills data and met local farmers and residents. "This collaboration allowed us to really dig into it, where all schools were pulling apart different pieces of it and then coming back and putting it all together."

The significance of the data quickly drew intrigue. What emerged was a picture of a few dedicated regulators - and even some industry leaders - who tried to introduce greater accountability, but these efforts were ultimately overwhelmed by larger forces.

"You start to understand these figures really do play a huge role in dictating the direction of the Canadian economy and that plays out in the lives of everyday Canadians," says Lauren Kaljur, a graduate of UBC's master of journalism program who has been investigating the concentration of corporate power in Saskatchewan's oil and gas industry since the beginning of 2017.

To Matthew Gilmour, a recent journalism graduate at Concordia University, after spending months populating spreadsheets and ledgers, "there's the human moment where you realize it's not just a pocketbook story. It's a human story. And people's lives are affected."

The work continued past the end of the semester in April 2017, with students working alongside veteran reporters at the Star, the National Observer and Global News to shape the stories, seek comments from all sides and publish hundreds of pages of government and industry records, detailing concerns about potentially deadly gas emissions for the first time. - Steph Wechsler/ Ryerson School of Journalism

Writers/Reporters

Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council

Watch the televised investigation: Sunday and Monday on Global National at 5:30 CT/MT/PT & 6:30 ET/AT

Robert Cribb can be reached at rcribb@thestar.ca[mailto:rcribb@thestar.ca]


NS 
gcat : Political/General News

RE 
cask : Saskatchewan | cana : Canada | namz : North America
