HD In-depth interview: Barrick’s Dushnisky and Goldcorp’s Garofalo on gold mining’s future
WC 5076 words
PD 12 June 2017
SN The Northern Miner
SC NMNR
LA English
CY Copyright 2017. The Northern Miner Group. All Rights Reseved.

LP 

At the Canadian Mining Symposium hosted by The Northern Miner at Canada House in London in early May, session moderator Greg Huffman, managing director and global head of mining sales at Canaccord Genuity, sat down with Barrick Gold (TSX: ABX; NYSE: ABX) president Kelvin Dushnisky and Goldcorp (TSX: G; NYSE: GG) CEO David Garofalo for an in-depth conversation on the strategies they use to guide both companies, plus a wider look at what the future holds for gold mining globally. The following is an edited transcript of the exchange.

Question: Looking at some of Goldcorp’s latest acquisitions such Gold Eagle, Virginia, Probe and Kaminak, is there now a premium on assets in safer jurisdictions, given the current political turmoil worldwide?

TD 

DAVID GAROFALO: It’s always been fundamental to Goldcorp’s strategy to stay in low political-risk jurisdictions — generally, investment-grade countries with the notable exception of taking a bit more risk in investing in Argentina prior to the Macri regime. But that was a generational asset in Cerro Negro, and it’s been born out in the changing regime there and the Macri economic model.

Fundamental to our story is that we’re predominantly focused on the Americas and our own time zones. It makes it an eminently more manageable company.

In my 27-year career I’ve worked with mining companies that are spread out across multiple jurisdictions on multiple continents, and it does introduce an element of risk and complexity to managing assets that makes it difficult to run the company, and certainly requires a risk premium associated with operating across too many jurisdictions.

One of the reasons Goldcorp historically has gotten a reasonably good multiple is because of its very stringent geographical and geological focus.

Q. Barrick has operations in many more countries. How, in terms of the decentralization of the company, how have you been able to structure that to deal with the increased complexity of jurisdictions and the risks associated with that?

KELVIN DUSHNISKY: In 2016, 70% of our production was from our five core mines in the Americas: Goldstrike, Cortez, Pueblo Viejo where we’re partnered with Goldcorp, Lagunas Norte and Veladero. And that represents about 50% of our reserves.

Outside of that, in some of the other jurisdictions where we’re operating, we factor in political, technical and financial risk. Part of what we try to do in terms of managing risk, is we try to develop various layers, starting with local procurement and hiring practices, understanding local politics and influences on policy — be it local, provincial or state, or federal — and ensuring that we have strong relationships in that respect.

We also look to jurisdictions where investment treaties could exist, ranging from Canada, which uses Foreign Investor Protection Agreements or even better, where we have free trade agreements with strong investor protection chapters. Those help us.

We layer in various strategies to try to manage risk and generally speaking, it’s worked out well.

Q. What do Canadians bring to the table that may separate us a little from some of the other mining nations?

DG: We do have a long mining history, and more importantly we have a mining infrastructure that comes with that. And I mean people infrastructure, not just physical infrastructure, that we’re able to export, whether it’s banking, legal or financial expertise that we’ve developed over more than a century in mining in Canada.

Accessing risk capital to work in the sector, predominantly within our own country but also we’ve been exporting that quite significantly over the last 30 years or so. Particularly as Latin America opened up as an investment, we were one of the first countries to rush in and develop, for example, the Chilean copper sector.

And that brought a whole new level of expertise to Canada that I think is the envy of the industry.

KD: I’d agree. The infrastructure exists, the services exist, the stock exchange and the predominance of publicly listed companies that trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange. And it’s more than that: it’s cultural — the familiarity with the space. Canada was mining before Canada was a country. Canada and mining, it’s a little bit like Italy and sports cars and the fashion industry. You don’t get that overnight.

From our perspective, it’s equally important that we protect it. Maintaining the brand is important. There’s a strong element of support from the Canadian government, and in our ability to wrap ourselves in the Canadian flag. We found that to be extremely effective as we operate abroad, in particular. It’s all part of the mix.

Generally speaking I think the country is perceived well. A recent example of that is other countries and jurisdictions adopting the Mining Association of Canada’s Towards Sustainable Mining framework for their own use. That’s very positive and reflects well on Canadian companies.

Q. Goldcorp and Barrick have very strong records of community engagement across your operations. Are Canadians doing enough on the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) front to maintain our social license as well as good reputation as responsible miners?

DG: When it comes to CSR, it’s all about water. And as an industry, we could certainly be a lot less water-intensive than we are. That’s a source of significant social conflict. It’s an impediment to getting both a social license to operate and getting projects permitted.

It’s the biggest factor in the space. As an industry, we need to make significant technological advancements in terms of reducing our water consumption in order to enhance our ability to develop projects.

That, by far, is the biggest impediment to developing projects. It causes untold conflict with surrounding communities. Even if you have the perception of utilizing scarce resources, even if it’s not true, against agricultural activity, you are not going to get the social license to operate.

We’ve seen example of that time and again in our space. And given how difficult it is for us to replace reserves, if we don’t attack that issue of water use in our industry, it’s going to be very difficult for us to perpetuate our businesses in the long run.

Q. Recently Barrick and Goldcorp partnered on the Cerro Casale-Caspiche assets which are obviously in a very water-sensitive area. Do you see some synergies by putting these projects together, from a permitting, water-usage and cost perspective?

KD: We certainly hope so, and that was the purpose of us coming together. We’re enthusiastic about the new partnership and think Goldcorp will bring some fresh perspective, thinking and energy to that situation.

Cerro Casale is interesting in that we have water rights that are important. These are water rights that relate to a particular aquifer — without getting into the technical details — and that’s something that is relatively rare.

I agree with Dave that water could certainly be the industry’s Achilles heel if we don’t manage it carefully. Over the last year we have hired and put in place a vice-president for water, dealing with both near-term environmental issues and looking out over the longer term at policy and other issues that could affect us, both as a company and as an industry.

Q. What about on the government-relations standpoint? Permitting is a big aspect of that, but with the rebound in commodity prices are you starting to see indications that governments may be seeking a bigger slice of the pie? And are there ways for industry to better insulate investors from this risk?

KD: Part of what we as a company and industry can improve on is to better communicate to host governments and locally the benefits that come from mining. For example, for 2016 alone, we spent around US$5.3 billion in various jurisdictions where we’re operating as taxes, royalties, wages, local procurement, etc.

I don’t think we’ve communicated well enough to governments the timelines associated with our investment. There’s a sense that as soon as you make the investment, you’re generating big returns, when the reality we all know is it takes a long time to pay back all our capital in this business.

Q. What about personnel risk? Where do you see the greatest skills shortages in the industry right now?

DG: I think it’s trades. A lot of trades have skills that are transferable to an urban environment. If you’re trying to raise a family or, for that matter, start a family or a relationship, it’s much easier to do in an urban environment than it is if you’re a young person in a mining camp or an isolated part of the world where you might be mining. That’s a significant challenge.

I don’t think we’ve done a very good job — at least in Canada — of importing those skills that we require, because trade schools are not turning out enough people to meet our shortages, whether it’s mechanics or electricians and the like. These are skills that are easily transported into urban environments, so we have to pay a premium to get them, but there’s just not enough of them even if we’re paying the premium.

KD: I agree with Dave, plus the traditional careers: engineers and geologists. We went through that period a decade or so ago when mining wasn’t the most attractive place, and kids weren’t going into the engineering and geology programs.

The other area where the biggest or equal challenge is going to come is attracting younger people into our space. We need people who can write code and have other skills beyond the classical trades.

We’ve done some survey work lately and if you ask kids who have recently graduated, would you rather go to Google or Facebook or Apple or Barrick, we’ve got a pretty high bar to get kids to come to a mining company.

We held recently — and I didn’t even know what this thing was until I was told — a “hackathon” where younger people assembled in a room and they brainstormed around a maintenance problem and a geological issue. We had kids from all over the place with different backgrounds coming at these various problems.

One of them interviewed at the very start and we asked him, “What do you think of the mining business?” And he said, “Who would go into it? It’s a dinosaur industry.”

At the end of the weekend, the response was actually very cool. They said there were a lot of areas where they could apply their talents and be innovative and creative.

As an industry we have to be more attractive to young people and send that message. The reality is, I can’t think of another business that touches on every single aspect of commerce, from financing, marketing, engineering to communication. Pick a topic area, and we touch on it one way or another, but that’s not well understood.

Q. Are the schools doing enough right now to groom the next generation of mining leaders?

KD: The Canadian schools are doing their part. They’re responding to demand, so part of what we need to do as an industry is to be supportive of the Canadian schools. We’re doing our part, but probably not as systematic as we should and could, and that’s something we’ll be focusing on.

In terms of succession, we have what we call “Barrick Academy” where we do more internally to groom the next generation of mining leaders, and that’s resonating well in the company.

We’re seeing an attraction of people to Barrick now. I’ll be honest with you, you go back three or four years ago and there was an outflow of talent from Barrick to our friends [grabs and shakes Garofalo jokingly]. We’re happy to see an inflow back, but we can’t get complacent — that’s the risk. We have to be vigilant and keep the space attractive.

Q. The market over the past year has started to look at production-growth profiles again, compared to 12 months ago when they mostly looked at free cash flow. For companies of your size it becomes hard to fill that production pipeline because you need big, meaningful assets. What’s the next step in de-risking those large assets from a financial aspect, i.e. raising the capital to buy and build these mega-projects.

DG:First you have to make an investment case, and that’s probably the biggest impediment to raising capital — finding the investment opportunities that generate an adequate rate of return to attract the capital.

As an industry we are facing a reserve cliff. Over the last five years in the gold sector we’ve seen a one-third decline in our reserves. In case you think that’s because we’re using lower gold price assumptions, that’s actually not true — it probably accounts for 30% of that decline. Seventy percent is actually depletion.

We haven’t been investing back in the ground, not only in terms of exploration, but also in terms of de-risking projects, bringing them though the pipeline and making that investment case to try to attract financing.

The capital is out there if you can demonstrate an adequate rate of return, but we haven’t de-risked large-scale projects sufficiently to replace what we’re depleting.

If you look at the production perspective, by our own admission, the industry will be shrinking production by 15% to 20% in the ensuing five years. And that’s because the declining reserves is the leading edge of that. Obviously production will decline as reserves decline.

So as an industry, we have to start to collaborate more. None of us should take on our shoulders individually the response of reversing that downward trajectory of reserves. We have to collaborate to bring meaningful projects forward.

And those projects are declining in grade. The average mining grade today of a gram a tonne is about half of what it was 15 years ago. So we have to do bulk tonnage, with bigger equipment, to deliver those economies of scale and make those lower grade deposits economic.

But none of us need to take on that capital risk ourselves, nor the project risk and technical risk.

The model we’re pursuing with Teck at NuevaUnion and with Barrick at Maricunga is one we have to pursue going forward, to share the financial and technical risk with well-capitalized partners.

So we avoid the Sudburys, the Nevadas, and for that matter the Red Lakes of the world where we built duplicative infrastructure on the same deposits and massively destroyed capital. And that drove away investors from the industry.

I’m encouraged by the fact that we have a new generation of CEOs in this space over the last four or five years that have a different mindset. They are taking that capital discipline and bringing it to bear within the sector, where traditionally that hasn’t been the case.

Q. Kelvin, you’ve partnered up on a number of assets over the last 18 months. Could you go through Barrick’s evaluative process for finding partners for various assets?

KD: The reality is we haven’t entered into a partnership yet where we don’t see a longer-term strategic fit. So it’s partly about capital, but not only about capital.

From our perspective — and I agree with everything David just said — we’re trying to de-risk projects to the extent we can, and build in stages whenever we can, instead of the “swing for the fences” model.

A real-life example of that is, we’re dealing with our Goldrush project in Nevada. Goldrush has 11 million ounces and growing, and when we first looked at the deposit, we did the classic “this is Nevada” approach and drew a 1 by 2 mile circle around it as a potential open pit and started thinking about how we could develop it.

Then we realized that could be interesting, but we’d prefer to develop Goldrush as a smaller, lower-capital underground mine. It’s quicker to bring it into production, and requires much less capital. In this case, there’s very little capital risk, as we’ll take advantage of the Cortez and Goldstrike facilities nearby. So it’s unique in that regard.

But to the extent that we can build in stages, and use cashflow to pay for subsequent stages, that how Goldstrike was built. It wouldn’t be a mine today if we had tried to build it all at once in the 1980s.

In terms of partners, one example is we sold half of our Zaldivar copper mine to Antofagasta because we had a view that, even though we thought we were running it well, they should probably be able to run it better than we could, given their synergies and their long history and understanding of operating in Chile. And that’s turned out to be the case. Just like if they had a single asset in Nevada, we should probably be able to run that mine better than they could.

We think Goldcorp is going to bring a lot to the equation at Cerro Casale, and there are synergies with their other activities in Chile.

In every instance, we’re looking for something strategic in the fit. And if we find that, then it makes sense for us to partner. And if not, we’re happy to run the asset on our own.

Q. David, you talked about the decline in reserve grades globally. With a lot of the low-hanging fruit gone, will a lot of the new generation of mines come from new discoveries, or is it going to be a new look at old deposits?

DG:Probably a combination thereof, and I know that’s a bit of a cop-out.

But as we see technological advancement, and the next frontier for us is artificial intelligence and driverless vehicles within our mines that will drive down labour costs, which is a big component of our cost structures.

That will allow us to relook at lower grade deposits that may not make the cut right now, to replace what we’re depleting.

Q. Barrick is making a big investment in new technology. Kelvin, what do you think could be the most game-changing or disruptive technology that will change our business?

KD: When we decentralized our business in recent years, what we found as we cleared away the middle layer between head office and the mines, was an increased flow of information between the two. We unclogged the artery.

But while we were in a position to make better decisions, what we were lacking was real-time data to make those decisions with. So part of our effort intensively over the last year has been digitization from the mines all the way to head office.

It’s a process, and it’s going to take us a while to get there. But already we’re finding the ability to make decisions more quickly. They’re simple things like short-interval controls — how we move people around, both in the open pit and underground in a more efficient way than we ever did in the past.

These are small things that really add up, shift after shift, week after week, month after month. We’re seeing gains that way.

Beyond that, the use of autonomous vehicles, especially underground, is something that will be very important to us. More of our mines are likely to be underground as we move to the next generation, so it’s going to be in even more compelling.

We’re trying to apply innovation throughout our business, from processing to better maintenance. We have a “code mine” which is kind of a mini-Google campus where we have code writers working with our mine operators to develop apps that make their day more efficient and easier, and we’re already seeing results from that.

So it’s a combination of things, rather than a one “eureka!” breakthrough.

Q. David, while at Agnico and Hudbay, you had a very effective strategy of actively investing in juniors with prospective discoveries and projects that you liked. Is grassroots exploration best left to the juniors, with seniors focusing on brownfields exploration near mines? Or is there a balance?

DG: I do think it requires a different mindset to do grassroots exploration, and it has a completely different risk profile and skill set. I think it is best left to the juniors.

Grassroots exploration is the highest-risk component of value creation within our industry.

Portfolio theory tells you that when you have risk, diversify it. Our strategy at Agnico, Hudbay and now Goldcorp was really to diversify that exploration risk through the juniors.

That also provides you the opportunity to leverage management in jurisdictions and districts that maybe you don’t have an expertise in.

Give them the capital, and if they’re successful, re-up. And if they’re not, cycle the capital to other another opportunity. That gives you some steady optionality in your pipeline, and you can populate your pipeline over time.

Q. Could you comment on using that approach when there are extended market downturns like the one we just came out of? Is there a better way to support exploration, or are we operating at the whim of the market?

DG: I think we can complement the market. When the juniors have access to capital markets, we tend to have less engagement with them, which is fine and we can watch them from afar.

But it’s good to be able to act as a bit of a merchant bank when the capital markets aren’t there.

Recently that hasn’t been the case, though not for all juniors. The market has been a bit surgical in terms of allocating capital to the junior space, and we’re been able enter the breach and that has given us exposure to some very good management teams and very prospective ground.

Q. Kelvin, what is Barrick's strategy when it comes to investing in juniors?

KD: We’ve announced in the last 18 months three particular investments: most recently with Atac Resources in the Yukon, before that with Osisko in northern Quebec, and before that Alicanto in Guyana. We like all three of those opportunities.

The approach we’re taking is certainly not a shotgun approach. We spent a lot of time evaluating the management teams, and we’re very pleased with the exploration groups that are on the ground. And our ability to participate in the program is supposed to be passive, in that respect.

You should expect to see more of that from us.

But at the same time, we’ve increased our budget both for brownfield and greenfield exploration. Part of that is because of the results we received at Goldrush in Nevada and Alturas in Chile and potentially extending into Argentina. Our finding cost is about US$25 an ounce, so we’re going to push ahead on both fronts.

Q. Going back to the Caspiche-Cerro Casale transaction, David you were quoted as saying that was done at about US$15 an ounce. So David, is it cheaper to find or buy ounces, and are you going to be looking for more at that US$10 to US$15 per ounce level?

DG: We’re always going to be looking for opportunities that have the potential to deliver 5 to 10 million ounces of reserves, and upwards of 500,000 ounces of annual production.

We do believe that the equilibrium level of production for a senior gold company is somewhere in the 3 to 4 million ounce a year range. And you want to do that with as few assets as possible so you have economies of scale inherent in the districts you operate in.

As a result, we’re always looking to increase value, not increase volume.

And that means driving down cost structures, but it also means, when you have the opportunity to upgrade your portfolio, do so.

And be quite ruthless about rotating capital from something at the bottom of your portfolio to something that can meaningfully move the needle both in terms of production volume over time and net asset value.

Q. Both companies have strong balance sheets. What are your thoughts on your abilities to pay out dividends to your shareholders?

DG: In a cyclical business it’s very, very difficult to have an ever-increasing dividend rate. Inevitably that creates an overhang in the stock. I’d sooner return capital in other forms if our balance sheet got a little sloppy.

If gold ran up to US$2,000 an oz. for a period of time and we had all sorts of excess cashflow and we didn’t have investment opportunities that met our hurdle rate, then you could do a special dividend, a share buyback or something like that.

The reality is we have a collection of finite-life assets, and I think shareholders by and large want us to compound our returns to the extent that we can actually generate opportunities that meet our hurdle rates. So I’d say our priority is regenerating our business given its finite nature.

KD: Paying a consistent dividend as part of total returns is important to us, and we like the discipline associated with that. But Dave is right, we’re at a point where the key over the last two years really was bringing down our debt and strengthening our balance sheet. We’ve reduced our debt by about 40% in the last two years, and liquidity is strong.

Depending on what happens you should expect us to look to increase the dividend, but we’ll be prudent about that. We’re not going to get ahead of ourselves.

Q. Royalty and streaming companies compete for the same investor capital that you as miners do. What are the biggest advantages for investors to put money directly into mining companies?

KD: I think there’s space for streamers, royalty companies and ETFs. The advantages in investing in solid, operating companies is our ability to take advantage of our respective pipelines and add value that way, for instance with exploration, and the ability to manage our costs well.

I think that’s going to be key: maintaining that level of discipline, including in a rising gold price environment. Because that’s not what we did during the last cycle when prices went up and we became a little undisciplined. We didn’t take advantage of margin expansion, and in that context you shouldn’t have been buying a gold company, and that’s just a reality.

Q. David, if we look at gold ETFs, they’ve become challenging for investors because they’ve somewhat outgrown the investable universe. We’re starting to see some ETF changes impact gold company valuations, more in the mid-tier and small-cap space. What is your overall take on the affinity investors have for ETFs over individual mining companies?

DG: It’s created a bit of a disconnect. And I’m not saying this to whine, it’s just a reality that an increasing amount of capital in equity markets is being managed by machines. And the machines are generally focused on the multiples and the valuation metrics that are prevalent across other industries, which are short-term price to earnings, short-term price to cashflow, etc.

And so what we’ve seen is a lot more volatility around quarterly earnings releases.

Of course, our investment horizon’s quite a bit longer in the mining space. It’s a minimum of a decade from discovery to first gold pour.

And so sometimes we have to make investment decisions for the long term that might not get the kind of traction in the marketplace in the short term.

That presents a challenge, and I don’t know what the answer is. Perhaps a much stronger metal price will resolve that in the short term.

Q. David, do you see a wave of consolidation coming in the gold space, particularly in the mid-tier?

DG: It’s challenging to do that, because there aren’t too many players of significance left in the gold sector. Quite often the companies that might be obvious targets for sector consolidation generally have a disparate collection of assets geographically and geologically that might not fit the existing portfolios of established producers.

So you’re ending up having to buy maybe five or six assets in a portfolio to get the one that you like. That erodes the value proposition when you do that, because then you have to go into the divestiture phase for the assets that are non-core. I can guarantee you are unlikely to realize the value if the bankers are pitching you going into that kind of transaction.

The model going forward for replacing reserves is to collaborate on large-scale opportunities and reduce the capital burden through that collaboration. This means consolidating districts and sharing the financial and technical risk required to bring some of these large-scale geological opportunities forward to mine production.

Q. How do we ensure Canada remains a sector leader globally in gold mining?

DG: It’s hard to kill. There was a lot of consternation that the base metals sector consolidated quite dramatically about ten years ago, but it’s like chopping off the top of a hedge — it grows back.

There’s that entrepreneurial class within the mining space in Canada that’s second to none. I don’t know as robust a junior sector that there is in Canada, and that’s helped regenerate the industry in a significant way, even after massive consolidation like that. And that’s true in the gold space as well.

KD: It’s in our DNA, and it’s up to us to protect it and promote it. We have the pole position, and I think we’ll continue to keep it.


CO 
bari : Barrick Gold Corp

IN 
igoldm : Gold Ore Mining | i211 : Metal Ore Mining | ibasicm : Basic Materials/Resources | imet : Mining/Quarrying

NS 
gdip : International Relations | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE

IPD

PUB 
The Northern Miner Group

AN 
Document NMNR000020170612ed6c00001


CLM Drumheller/Stettler Mla
SE Opinion
HD The myth of social license
BY Rick Strankman
CR Hanna Herald
WC 538 words
PD 7 June 2017
SN Hanna Herald
SC HANNAH
ED Final
PG A4
LA English
CY Copyright © 2017 Hanna Herald

LP 

A license is a permit from an authority to own or use something, do a particular thing, or carry on a trade or action. A license comes with restrictions and limitations that are typically limited by jurisdictional boundaries. As an example, if you were to hold a license that permits the holder to carry a firearm in Canada, that license possibly would not be recognized and you would not be permitted to carry a firearm in other countries.

Under the guise of what is turning out to be a fictitious form of licensed permission, the Alberta government introduced Bill 20, the Climate Leadership Implementation Act on May 24th, 2016. The Act was sold to Albertans by making claims that it would allow us implied permission to build the pipelines required to get our natural resources to market. One year later this claim is turning out to not be worth the paper it was written on.

TD 

The Alberta government's Climate Leadership Plan, which average Albertans know now as the Carbon Tax, has had a financial effect on virtually every single purchase we make. Besides the obvious direct cost on everyday consumer items, the plan has had an adverse effect on Alberta's energy sector which is obviously not in the provinces best interests.

The social license claims that accompanied the passage of the Alberta government's plan has apparently not been accepted by their British Columbian brethren, who have teamed up with the BC Green Party, who "are determined to immediately employ every tool available to the new government and stop the expansion of the Kinder Morgan pipeline" from being built. What we have learned is that licensing agreements that are expected to cross jurisdictional lines must have universal approval by the government, where the license is attempting to be used; something this Alberta government obviously did not do.

To say the social license myth being sold to us by our Alberta government has been a failure is an understatement. MLA for Chestermere Rockyview, Leela Aheer delivered an impassioned Member's Statement that captured what the government's social license has amounted to.

"For two years this government has been imposing ideological tax hikes and caps on our oil sands, all in the name of social license. The Premier conned Albertans, undermined the authority and integrity of our national energy regulators to excuse her long-held radical environmental agenda." -Leela Aheer The Alberta government have created an unspoken pact with the LEAP Manifesto and environmental radicals like Tzeporah Berman, who after the BC NDP and Green Party announced their coalition government, celebrated on Twitter by saying "this a turning point for BC." This is hardly a productive attitude coming from a member of the Alberta Oilsands advisory group.

It appears that social license is nothing more than the snake oil its perceived benefits are turning out to be. The cost to Albertans for this snake oil is real and it can be measured in financial, job, and investment losses. It would serve the Premier and the Alberta government well to stop working for the environmental radicals, quit perpetuating the myth of social license, and start working for Albertans.


NS 
ncolu : Columns | c13 : Regulation/Government Policy | ccat : Corporate/Industrial News | ncat : Content Types | nfact : Factiva Filters | nfcpin : C&E Industry News Filter

RE 
cana : Canada | caab : Alberta | namz : North America

IPD 
Column | license,permit,authority,something,particular,thing

PUB 
Postmedia Network Inc.

AN 
Document HANNAH0020170607ed670000c


HD Feds back motion in support of Trans Mountain, despite B.C. government turmoil
CR The Canadian Press 
WC 229 words
PD 6 June 2017
ET 13:38
SN The Canadian Press - Broadcast wire
SC BNW
LA English
CY (c) 2017 The Canadian Press. All rights reserved.

LP 

OTTAWA — The federal Liberal government has thrown its weight behind an opposition motion backing Kinder Morgan's Trans Mountain pipeline expansion even as political turmoil in British Columbia continues to threaten the project's future.

The motion, brought by Conservative MP Mark Strahl, affirms that the project has social license to proceed, is critical to the economy, is environmentally sound and should proceed as planned.

TD 

The motion passed Tuesday by a vote of 252-51, with the backing of all Liberal MPs, except two B.C. backbenchers who have criticized the project in the past.

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau last fall approved the project to twin the Trans Mountain pipeline between Edmonton and Burnaby, B.C. and B.C. Premier Christy Clark came to support it in January after five conditions she placed on it had been met.

However Clark could lose her hold on power later this month under an agreement between the province's NDP and Green Party to work together to form government, including a plan to oppose the Trans Mountain expansion.

Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr last week said the government would support Strahl's motion because the project remains a sound one with license to proceed, even though he admitted aligning himself with the Conservatives made him uncomfortable.


IN 
i1 : Energy

NS 
gpol : Domestic Politics | gcat : Political/General News | gpir : Politics/International Relations

RE 
cana : Canada | namz : North America

IPD 
National | Oil&Gas | Politics

PUB 
The Canadian Press

AN 
Document BNW0000020170606ed6600gl9


HD  John Horgan One-On-One
WC 1088 words
PD 4 June 2017
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2017 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): EVAN SOLOMON

RACHEL NOTLEY (Alberta Premier): And mark my words, that pipeline will be built. The decisions have been made and it is in the best interests of Albertans, Canadians and in particular, might I say, British Columbians.

TD 

SOLOMON: Well, there it is. The Alberta premier's message to her BC NDP colleague. John Horgan is very clear. Do not block that pipeline. This is shaping up to be maybe the blockbuster fight of the summer. On one side, you've got Alberta's NDP premier, Rachel Notley and Justin Trudeau. They want to build the Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain pipeline from Edmonton to Burnaby, BC. On the other side, you've got the BC NDP, who just struck up a partnership the BC Green party, and they are poised to seize power from the BC Liberals, who are just one seat short of a majority and whose government could fall within weeks. And if he does become the next premier, what will John Horgan do about the pipeline, and other issues? Well, let's find out. John Horgan joins us now. First of all, thanks for joining us on "Question Period".

JOHN HORGAN (BC NDP Leader): Good morning, Evan.

SOLOMON: Is the Kinder Morgan pipeline dead if you become the premier.

HORGAN: Well, certainly, it's a divisive issue in British Columbia, and one that we've been following for a number of years now. In fact, going back to 2011, 2012 when Kinder Morgan started accelerating their plans to twin the existing pipeline. It's divisive issue and we know now that a number of First Nations in the Burrard Inlet area are already in court. The Tsleil-Waututh, the Musqueam and the Squamish nations do not want to see this pipeline proceed into their territory. The city of the Burnaby, the city of the Vancouver are big players in British Columbia, of course. And, and now we'll have a government of New Democrats and Greens that are concerned that the impact of a seven-fold increase on tanker traffic through our major metropolitan area, through the Salish Sea and up the Strait Juan de Fuca is not in our interest, and we're going to be absolutely clear on that.

SOLOMON: Okay. I want to be, let me try to be more clear. Is the pipeline dead? If you become the premier, are you going to say no and try to block that pipeline, because you know the federal government has the jurisdiction to ram it through if they want. They've got the constitutional power. Would you let that happen?

HORGAN: I understand the position that Mr. Trudeau is in. Rachel Notley is a friend of mine. We have agreed to disagree on the pipeline issue. We have many other issues of agreement. But on this fundamental question, British Columbian's interests have to come first for me.

SOLOMON: Okay. The environment minister, just on the program, Catherine McKenna, she said she'd be willing to negotiate with you on that, to make assure this pipeline goes through, get that so-called social license. Would you be willing to negotiate with the federal government to try to get a Kinder Morgan pipeline twinned?

HORGAN: I'm anxious to sit down with the prime minister to talk about a range of issues. First and foremost for me would be, of course, softwood lumber. I was excited to see the federal response late last week to the, the, what is going to be a looming crisis in the forest sector here in British Columbia. Fifty percent of the trade between Canada and the US on softwood is the result of BC forests, and BC workers, and I want to ensure that we have a clear understanding that the federal government's going to be there for BC workers and we're going to be aggressive on that trade file. There's a whole number of issues at I am excited to work with the prime minister on - housing, the Fentanyl crisis, the list is much longer the things that we agree on...

SOLOMON: No, I get that, and I...

HORGAN: ...than those that we disagree.

SOLOMON: Just tell me. Are you willing to negotiate, so there's still a possibility that you would also accept that pipeline?

HORGAN: I will address that when the opportunity presents itself, Evan. I've laid out how the First Nations in the region and the two mayors in the major cities in the Burrard Inlet feel about this. I'm going to consult with attorney general's ministry upon forming a government and look at our legal options at that time. We have a number of other tools in the toolbox when it comes to permitting, and we'll follow through on those. I'm happy to sit down with the prime minister at an early opportunity to talk about pipelines, to talk about softwood, to talk about Fentanyl, to talk about childcare...

SOLOMON: Okay.

HORGAN: ...housing and on and on it goes.

SOLOMON: And I'm, I assume you'll be dealing with Donald Trump on softwood lumber, on energy issues. If you become the premier, I guess he's an early visit for you, right?

HORGAN: Well, I've made it quite clear in my election campaign that that one of my first orders of business is to go Washington and make it clear. Rachel Notley's gone to protect the interests of Alberta. Brad Wall has gone to protect the interests of Saskatchewan. We need to have a BC representative making it abundantly clear that we have had a positive working relationship with the United States for many, many decades and we want to continue that. But we're not patsies here, and we have cards to play. As I say, the Columbia River treaty being first among them.

SOLOMON: All right, John Horgan, could be the next premier of British Columbia in the next couple of weeks. We are watching that very closely. Sir, thank you very much for joining us. Appreciate it.

HORGAN: Thank you, Evan. Appreciate it.

SOLOMON: Coming up on "Question Period", the US joins Syria and Nicaragua as the three countries who have now opted out of the Paris climate accord. Is that good or bad for the economy here in Canada? The scrum is next, and our special guest from New York MSNBC's host, Ali Velshi joins us. Stay with "Question Period".

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

Document QUES000020170605ed6400003


HD The Scrum Part II
WC 2323 words
PD 4 June 2017
SN Question Period
SC QUES
LA English
CY © Copyright 2017 CTV Television Inc. All Rights Reserved.

LP 

Host(s): EVAN SOLOMON

PHILIPPE COUILLARD (Quebec Premier): We are all Quebecers, and therefore we can all say in French and in English, (speaking in French). Being a Quebecer is our way of being Canadians.

TD 

SOLOMON: It's back. That's right. The most divisive debate in the country, the one that almost tore Canada apart has been shockingly re-opened by Quebec Premier Philippe Couillard. He argues that Canada's 150th birthday is the perfect time to crack open the Constitution and make Quebec a distinct society. Well the scrum is back to tackle that one. Stephanie Levitz is back. Joyce Napier is back. Craig Oliver is back. And we now bring our special guests, filmmaker Avi Lewis, who is the strategic director of the LEAP, which called for an end to, among other things, more development of the oilsands. Thanks for being, Avi, and joining the scrum. I'm going to start with you. We all remember these debates about the Constitution, the distinct society, Mulroney, boy, why do you think Philippe Couillard is doing this now?

AVI LEWIS (Strategic Director of the LEAP): I think he's feeling pressure from the sovereigntist left. I think, I think he's got Gabriel Nadeau-Dubois fear. He's seeing, we've seen the PQ abandon being a left-wing party, essentially, and become a neo Liberal austerity party, and we're seeing the rise of the Quebec Solidaire, and all of a sudden Couillard realizes that young people in Quebec are galvanized, not necessarily by sovereignty, but by a progressive agenda, which is represented in his province now by a sovereignist party. So, I think we may be seeing a reconfiguration of the landscape. It took them a while to get the whole issue that there might be a little problem between Quebec and the rest of the Canada. So now he's trying to make up some ground locally.

SOLOMON: Well, Craig, here we go again. What do you think about it?

CRAIG OLIVER (CTV News): I've spent years of my life...

(LAUGHTER)

OLIVER: ...on an intellectual forced march, chasing around constitutional talks, and I'll tell you one thing about them - whatever nobility they may start in, they end in mud. And what Couillard is doing is being a political powder monkey. That's what they call the guy on a construction crew in charge of dynamite who blows things up. He's going to blow up every, this whole issue. Everybody will want to get into it. There will be endless fights and squabbles and it could end with defeated governments. It could end with the country up for grabs again, as we've seen in the past. This could be a mess.

SOLOMON: All right. If it is a, political expediency, Joyce, as, as Avi argues, is he playing with dynamite, as Craig says.

JOYCE NAPIER (CTV News): Absolutely, and I think, yeah, totally, that's a great imagine. First of all, it's so 1990s, you know, let me get with the program. That was a long time ago. Those of us who had the pleasure of covering those debates know these long debates about commas, or semicolons. It's just doesn't work. It's 1990s. Let's bring back shoulder pads and, why not, Farrah Fawcett hair. I don't know. Why is he digging this out? It could blow up in his face, because if indeed Avi is right, and he wants to counter this, this sort of rising conservativism, or progressive wave in Quebec, it may also turn against him, right? The rest of the country doesn't want it. And you don't just open a little bit of a constitutional debate. We all know it. It's going to open it big and wide and then we're going to put everything in there.

SOLOMON: ...you can't get control...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

NAPIER: Equalization, and so on, and so forth. I mean, it's not only that. So what is he looking for? I don't know. I've been scratching my head. I can't figure it out.

SOLOMON: Well, it's a time of, there's big things going on. There's big trade negotiations. I'm sure the federal government is not happy. Justin Trudeau immediately said, we are not interested in this. He was unequivocal. Is this the kind of thing that once you open it, the separatists love it, you know, this thing starts and it's uncontrollable?

STEPHANIE LEVITZ (The Canadian Press): And Joyce, talked about how it's so 1990s, but I think it's so 2017. I mean, here we are in this populist revolt scenario around the world while all sorts of voter populations are looking at challenging the status quo, and I think to Avi's point...

NAPIER: ...(inaudible) the Constitution?

LEVITZ: ...there are people that are, there are people that are hungry for change. There are people that are hungry for making things different. And if there is a sense, whether it's economic, whether it's social, whether it's religious, whatever, that the elites, that people aren't speaking for them. That's where you get these populist uprisings, right?

SOLOMON: I would understand that, but it's Couillard himself that's opened it, right?

NAPIER: Yeah.

SOLOMON: This is what I don't understand.

LEWIS: But Evan, Evan...

SOLOMON: Yeah.

LEWIS: ...Evan, let us, let us, can we not let the Constitution of the country, and its discussion, be determined by the ennui and historical boredom of the journalist class?

(LAUGHTER)

LEWIS: Come on Folks. I mean, I covered the, I covered the referendum for Much Music in '95. We had a, we had a show planned for fifteen minutes, and we were on the air for five hours. I've got my own scars. But, but look, Quebec never signed the darn thing. It is an open wound in the country. Don't just dismiss it because you're bored of it. Don't say because there are semicolons, we have to shy away from it. There's lots of things that could be fixed in that Constitution. I think if you start talking to Indigenous communities across this country...

OLIVER: How, how can they...

LEWIS: I think you start talking to other people, there's lots of appetite to have a better Constitution for Canada.

OLIVER: How can they want to opt in, when they never opted out.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

LEWIS: And I'm not bored of it. I'm not bored. Craig, you may be bored.

OLIVER: And they never opted out, so how can they opt in? They've got three seats on the Supreme Court. The own a quarter of the, the senate. The idea that they somehow have opted out, and they want back in, it just doesn't work.

SOLOMON: This, okay, I would say, it is fair to say that a constitutional wound is not fixed. I guess the question is for Philippe Couillard, why try to do it now? Timing matters in politics, and speaking of timing, at one point, Justin Trudeau had timing on his hand. He had an NDP government in Alberta that said, okay, we'll put a cap on oilsands emissions. We'll buy into your price on carbon. Give us the Trans Mountain, the Kinder Morgan pipeline from Alberta to Burnaby, BC. He had a Liberal government in BC that said, okay, you know, we'll, we'll do that. Now with the results in BC, which could be an NDP-Green government. Avi Lewis, is Kinder Morgan dead?

LEWIS: Yeah. Yeah, I think it effectively is. It might well have been otherwise. There's something called an extraordinary coalition of First Nations, that is already in the way, the treaty alliance to, to stop the pipelines. There were going to be court challenges. There were challenges from cities in, in British Columbia. It was never the sure thing that Notley and Trudeau wanted to present it as. But I think Christy Clark might have lost this election on Kinder Morgan. Sixty percent of the province voted for parties who were very clear on the position. And I think it's revealed, what I'm really excited about in this moment is just that we can refocus the debate on the principles and the facts and the benefits to people in different parts of this land, instead of having politicians blaming, this sort of caricature of environmentalists for being against pipelines.

SOLOMON: Yeah, here's what I don't understand...

LEWIS: It's the people of British Columbia that are against it.

SOLOMON: Rachel Notley's an NDP premier. "Mark my words," she says, Stephanie. "That pipeline will be built." So now you've got an NDP premier in Alberta telling a potential NDP premier in British Columbia, like, showdown. My political life depends on your decision. How does that play out?

LEVITZ: I mean, I think it's so fascinating because, you know, premier, the prime minister has staked so much on this concept of social license, right, of convincing people to come onside, and his whole argument that environmental benefits require economic benefits and all of these things and now he's looking down, and how much political capital is Justin Trudeau going to want to spend on this thing?

SOLOMON: Joyce?

NAPIER: He was asked clearly in Rome, and you know, he's usually on talking points. It's hard sometimes to get a real answer from the prime minister, or even his cabinet. And I asked him that question, specifically, are you willing to go against their will? Talking obviously about the NDP-Green coalition, and his answer was crystal clear, it was "yes". Those were fighting words coming from the prime minister of Canada.

OLIVER: Let's remember that an awful lot of the people who voted for him as a Liberal in British Columbia voted NDP in the election. They are strong environmentalists. Trudeau has a lot to lose here. But he's stuck now. He's got to not just fight for this pipeline. He's got to endorse this pipeline, because he and the pipeline, their fates are entwined.

SOLOMON: And so, and Rachel Notley's fate may be entwined, as well.

NAPIER: Yeah, but we're assuming, but we're assuming this vote was just against pipelines. Maybe it was just against, they, they wanted change. Maybe the voters there wanted change.

SOLOMON: You may be right.

LEWIS: I think, I think there's a much bigger, there's a much bigger issue here. Evan, when you started the show here, we go again, I thought we were going into the pipeline debate. Like how, here we are, day after day, month after month debating these 19th century economic levers. Where is the renewable energy project that stands like a beacon, a nation building project from coast to coast to coast in this country, that actually announces Canada, in the abdication of the United States from real climate progress, we have an opportunity lead the world in renewable energy. We have extraordinary capacity here and we have communities across the country that are already doing it on a small scale because we're missing the big picture. Where's the vision for this 21st century economy that could lead the Canada?

SOLOMON: Okay last word to Stephanie.

LEVITZ: But to pay it for, you need the export the oil, and, and that's the problem that Justin Trudeau has right?

LEWIS: No you don't.

LEVITZ: If he wants the money fund his...

LEWIS: No, that's just, that's just not true.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

LEVITZ: ...natural resource.

LEWIS: That's just absolutely not true. That's absolutely not true. We've got...

SOLOMON: Well, Avi, I'll give you ten seconds on this one.

LEWIS: We have corporations enough money to pay the national debt. There's plenty of money in this Canada...

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

SOLOMON: Although the fate of Rachel Notley might be tied up. If she doesn't get a pipeline and there's a united Conservative movement in Alberta, then what happens to Justin Trudeau's national price on carbon?

LEWIS: You know the price on carbon, we're seeing all the pressure now being framed, mostly by like, okay, I'll say it, Ottawa pundits like you, as pressure from the now retrograde nihilist, denialist United States, that suddenly a carbon price is going to be a hindrance to Canada's economy. Actually, look what Emmanuel Macron did after Trump pulled out of the, out of the Paris deal. He went on national television, and he said engineers, entrepreneurs, I want you to think of France as your second homeland. Come and let's build a renewable energy future together. What do we get from Justin Trudeau? Deeply disappointed.

SOLOMON: Right.

LEWIS: Come on. (Inaudible) vision here. There's huge, huge opportunity.

SOLOMON: It's true. I, I've got to go, but I will say, from Mr. Macron, strong words from a country that has 60 percent, plus, of its energy is nuclear energy. I wonder if you'd support that.

LEWIS: Fair enough. And you know how much it cost me to say anything good about that neo Liberal streak, as well.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

SOLOMON: Well, there you go. All right...

LEWIS: It's not something I do, it's not something I do readily.

That is Avi Lewis. That is Joyce Napier, Stephanie Levitz and Craig Oliver, I want to thank as all of you for being here. Great to have you on the program. A big week ahead, by the way. The government will announce its long-awaited plan for Canada's military. We've got our eyes on that.
